CLINICAL ENDPOINTS. The primary endpoint of the PROSPECT study was the composite endpoint of cardiac death or arrest, myocardial infarction, or rehospitalization for unstable or progressive angina. The IBIS-4 study had an imaging-based endpoint (i.e., the change in the percent atheroma volume at 13-month follow-up). However, in the IBIS 4 study, which was a sub-study of the COMFORTable-AMI (Comparison of Biolimus Eluted from an Erodible Stent Coating with Bare Metal Stents in Acute ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction) study, clinical endpoints were also recorded, including cardiac death, myocardial infarction, and target and nontarget lesion revascularization. In the IBIS 4 study, revascularization was deemed clinically indicated at follow-up angiography when there was a percent diameter stenosis (%DS) of $70% on QCA or 70% $ %DS $50% and recurrent angina or evidence of ischemia at rest or during an exercise test. The clinical, angiographic, and intravascular imaging data in both studies enabled identification of untreated lesions that were assessed by VH-IVUS at baseline and caused events. The present analysis focused on these lesions; the primary endpoint of this study was the combined endpoint of cardiac death, myocardial infarction, or revascularization because of progressive or unstable angina, because of evidence of ischemia and 70% $ %DS $ 50% on follow-up coronary angiography, or because of significant disease progression (%DS $70%) at follow-up angiography (MACE-R). The secondary endpoint of the present analysis was the combined endpoint of cardiac death, myocardial infarction, or revascularization because of progressive or unstable angina (MACE). STUDIED LESIONS AND VH-IVUS ANALYSIS. In the PROSPECT study, 25 of the untreated lesions at baseline that were studied by VH-IVUS and caused events had a thin cap fibroatheroma (TCFA) phenotype, 18 untreated lesions had a thick cap fibroatheroma (ThCFA) phenotype, 7 had a non-fibroatheroma phenotype, and 4 were unclassified lesions. In the IBIS 4 study, all the lesions associated with MACE-R had either a TCFA (n ¼ 13) or a ThCFA (n ¼ 2) phenotype (2,4). The present analysis included only untreated lesions with a lipid-rich phenotype (TCFA or ThCFA) that caused MACE-R during follow-up and a 4fold sample of lesions with a lipid-rich phenotype that remained quiescent. Lesions that were short (<9 mm), those with suboptimal angiographic images (i.e., poor opacification of lumen silhouette, excessive foreshortening, or overlapping), and cases in which the DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) file did not include all the necessary information for 3D-QCA reconstruction were excluded from the analysis. VH-IVUS data analysis was performed by independent core laboratories (Cardiovascular Research Foundation, New York, New York in PROSPECT and Cardialysis B.V., Rotterdam, the Netherlands in IBIS-4). Classification of remodeling pattern and lesion phenotype was performed in both core laboratories using the same protocol (Supplemental Appendix). For each lesion with a TCFA or ThCFA phenotype its remodeling pattern, its length, the length of the proximal shoulder of the lesion, the distance ostium of the studied vessel to minimum lumen area (MLA) of the lesion, its MLA, external elastic membrane, plaque area, and PB at the MLA were estimated and recorded. 3D-QCA RECONSTRUCTION, BLOOD FLOW SIMULATION, AND DATA PROCESSING. Anatomical landmarks (i.e., side branches) seen in both IVUS and x-ray angiography were used to identify the proximal and distal end of the "segment of interest" (i.e., the segment that was assessed by VH-IVUS) on coronary angiography. Two end-diastolic angiographic projections (>25 apart) where there was no overlapping or foreshortening of the segment of interest and that allowed accurate delineation of the lumen silhouette were selected and used to reconstruct its anatomy using well-validated software (QAngio XA 3D RE, Medis, Leiden, the Netherlands) (8). The distances proximal end of the segment of interest to the proximal end of each TCFA/ThCFA and distal end of the segment of interest to the distal end of each TCFA/ ThCFA were used to identify lesion location in 3D-QCA models. Then, 3D-QCA analysis was performed for each lesion, and the lesion length, minimum lumen diameter (MLD), and %DS were estimated. The 3D-QCA models were processed with computational fluid dynamic techniques, and the ESS distribution was estimated (Supplemental Appendix). The location of each TCFA/ThCFA lesion was identified in the 3D-QCA models and the lesion was then divided into consecutive 3-mm segments. The ESS values were extracted across the circumference and length of the segment for each of these segments, and the mean value was calculated (3,4). For each lesion, the highest and lowest mean ESS values, estimated in the 3-mm segments of the lesion, were recorded and defined the maximum and minimum lesion ESS, respectively. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS. Numerical variables are presented as median (interquartile range [IQR]), whereas categorical variables are presented as absolute values and percentages. The Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare numerical variables between lesions associated with MACE-R or MACE and those that remained quiescent, whereas categorical variables were compared using the chi-square test. Cox regression analysis was used to identify VH-IVUS, 3D-QCA, and 3D-QCA-derived hemodynamic predictors associated with MACE-R or MACE. Receiver-operating characteristics curve analysis was performed for each variable associated with MACE-R (p < 0.05); those with the highest area under the curve that were not collinear (r < 0.50) were entered into a multivariate model. Receiver-operating characteristics curve analysis was also used for the computational fluid dynamicderived variables to identify the best cutoff that predicted MACE-R; this was used to classify lesions in groups. Kaplan-Meier plots were used to display time to event at lesion and patient levels; comparison of the MACE-R rate between groups with different plaque characteristics and hemodynamic profiles was performed using the log-rank test. Lesions or patients with no events were censored at the latest contact date. In case of multiple lesions in the same patient, the lesion with the highest maximum ESS value or the lesion that exhibited the highest pressure gradient was used in the patient-level analysis. Analyses were performed in Stata version 15.1 (StataCorp LP, College Station, Texas) and R version 3.4.2 (R Foundation, Vienna, Austria). A p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant. RESULTS PATIENT DEMOGRAPHICS. In the PROSPECT study, 54 MACE occurred during a median of 3.4 years of follow-up. In the IBIS 4 study, 15 MACE-R events occurred (9 cardiac events and 6 revascularizations) within 5 years of follow-up. After excluding cases who had IVUS analysis or co-registration with coronary angiography was not possible, cases in whom there was insufficient information for 3D-QCA reconstruction in the DICOM files, lesions with short length, and those with a nonlipid-rich phenotype, 28 MACE-R lesions (n ¼ 26) were included in the present analysis (16 from the PROSPECT study and 12 from the IBIS-4 study). Revascularization was performed in 6 lesions during invasive assessment at 13-month follow-up either because of new-onset angina and a 70% $ %DS $ 50% (n ¼ 1) or significant disease

A total of 92 patients (45 recruited from PROS-PECT and 47 from the IBIS 4 study; 119 vessels) were included in the present analysis. FIGREF190.text: For the first time, the present study evaluated the prognostic value of the 3D-QCA-derived hemodynamic indexes and plaque characteristics in stratifying nonflow limiting lesions that were likely to progress and cause MACE-R or MACE. We found that:1) ESS distribution estimated in 3D-QCA models provided additional prognostic information and was an independent predictor of MACE-R or MACE; 2) the pressure gradient across nonflow limiting lipid-rich lesions was a predictor of MACE-R and/or MACE; 3) the combination of plaque characteristics and 3D-QCA-derived hemodynamic indexes (i.e., ESS or the pressure gradient across the lesion) enabled more accurate detection of MACE-R and MACE lesions than VH-IVUS-derived variables; and 4) plaque morphology and the hemodynamic variables estimated in 3D-QCA models allowed more accurate identification of the patients who were at risk to experiencing cardiovascular event than standalone VH-IVUS imaging. Computational fluid dynamic-based animal and human studies have provided robust evidence about the role of the local hemodynamic forces on atherosclerotic disease progression and have highlighted their prognostic implications (9). Low ESS appears to promote, through mechano-transduction pathways, plaque evolution and the development of high-risk plaques and in clinical studies, low ESS was reported to be a predictor of lesions that progressed and caused events (3,10). Conversely, the role of high ESS on the formation of high-risk plaques is less well established; however, there is considerable evidence to suggest that high ESS contributes to the destabilization of vulnerable lesions (11,12). Despite the undoubted prognostic implications of ESS, blood flow simulation analyses have limited applications in the clinical arena. This should be at least partially attributed to the increased time required for coronary reconstruction and blood flow modeling.In the present study we examined the prognostic value of 3D-QCA-derived hemodynamic variables in detecting nonflow-limiting lipid-rich plaques that are likely to progress and cause MACE-R. In contrast to findings reported in previous studies, we found that the maximum and not the minimum ESS predicted MACE-R and MACE(3,4). This discrepancy might be attributed to the different modality used to extract vessel geometry; 3D-QCA modeling has limited

VH-IVUS ¼ virtual histology-intravascular ultrasound; other abbreviations as in Figure 2. efficacy in assessing details in lumen morphology, which can affect ESS estimations, especially in complex long lesions that are likely to exhibit ESS heterogeneity (13). In the present study, in which the median lesion length was 22.7 mm, IVUS and 3D-QCA MLA co-located in only 40% of lesions, a finding that highlights the limited accuracy of 3D-QCA to accu-, C.V. et al. J Am Coll Cardiol Img. 2020;13(10):2206-19.

FIGREF193.text: . Taking into account the limitations of 3D-QCA and the fact that it generates smooth luminal surfaces, we used the mean rather the more commonly used minimum predominant ESS value to define the physiological profile of 3-mm segments(3,4).Despite the limitations of 3D-QCA-modeling, the estimated hemodynamic indexes, and in particular, the ESS distribution provided useful prognostic information and improved the efficacy of established VH-IVUS-derived plaque characteristics in predicting events (Figure 3, Central Illustration). The maximum ESS was a predictor of lesion-related MACE-R/MACE in multivariable analysis, and the Kaplan-Meier plots demonstrated the synergetic effect of plaque morphology and ESS in predicting future MACE or angiographically indicated revascularizations. Two recent studies, the EMERALD (Exploring the Mechanism of Plaque Rupture in Acute Coronary Syndrome Using Coronary CT Angiography and Computational Fluid Dynamics) and a post hoc analysis from the FAME II reported similar findings to our analysis, demonstrating that the maximum ESS estimated in lesions reconstructed by computed tomography/coronary angiography or 3D-QCA were predictors of future myocardial infarctions (6,14). However, these studies included predominantly flow-limiting lesions (49% and 100% of the lesions included in the

FIGREF195.text: Lesions were classified in groups according to the presence or absence of (A) $2 high-risk plaque features and increased maximum ESS values (>4.95 Pa), (B) $2 high-risk plaque features and a high-pressure gradient (>2.31 mm Hg) across the lesion, (C) PB $70% and MLA #4 mm 2 and increased maximum ESS values, and (D) PB $70% and MLA #4 mm 2 and a high-pressure gradient. Abbreviations as in Figures 1 and 2.EMERALD and FAME II studies had fractional flow reserve #0.80, respectively) that should have been considered for revascularization. Conversely, our analysis focused on nonflow limiting stenoses, with a median pressure gradient across these lesions of only 1.95 mm Hg (IQR: 1.14 to 3.33 mm Hg), for which there was lack of evidence to support their invasive passivation. In addition, the EMERALD study predominantly included patients without a history of coronary artery disease who were less likely to have complex lesions, whereas in the FAME II study there was no information about plaque composition. Therefore, this analysis was unable to examine the additive predictive value of hemodynamic indexes over anatomic and morphological plaque characteristics derived by intravascular imaging. Finally, coronary reconstruction and blood flow simulation in both studies was computationally demanding because the EMERALD used computed tomographic coronary angiography derived models, whereas the FAME II study incorporated the side branches in the 3D-QCA models, which considerably increased computation time. Conversely, our analysis included only the main branch and assumed steady coronary flow; this approach makes the real-time estimation of ESS feasible while the patient is in the catheterization laboratory. The unfavorable implications of high ESS on plaque pathobiology is supported by several experimental studies that have shed light on the mechano-

FIGREF197.text: were classified in groups according to the presence or absence of (A) high-risk plaques (i.e., plaques with $2 high-risk features) and increased maximum ESS values (>4.95 Pa), (B) high-risk plaques and a high-pressure gradient (>2.31 mmHg) across the lesion, (C) PB $70% and MLA #4 mm 2 and increased maximum ESS values, and (D) lesions with PB $70%, MLA #4 mm 2 , and a high-pressure gradient. degradation of the fibrous cap by inhibiting extracellular matrix synthesis, as well as increases smooth muscle cell apoptosis and proteolytic matrix degradation(9). The preceding processes eventually result in fibrous cap fragility and rupture that can cause vessel thrombosis or plaque healing with accelerated disease progression(15). These events can have clinical manifestations if they occur in segments with increased PB and small MLA because in this setting they are likely to cause flow obstruction and ischemia(16). In our study, apart from ESS, increased PB and small MLA were also predictors of MACE-R, whereas PB was also an independent predictor of MACE-R in the multivariate Cox regression analysis.Interestingly, apart from ESS, the pressure gradient across the lesion estimated in our 3D-QCA models also provided useful prognostic information and was a predictor of MACE-R and MACE. Kaplan-Meier analysis showed that lesions with a high pressure gradient (and especially those with high-risk plaque characteristic) had a poor prognosis, with event rates as high as 51.8% at 5-year follow-up. Several studies demonstrated that a low fractional flow reserve was a predictor of worse outcomes even in angiographically nonflow limiting stenoses(17). In these studies, the prognostic value of fractional flow reserve was attributed to the fact that it reflected atherosclerotic burden. However, in our analysis and in the EMERALD study, the pressure gradient seemed to provide additional prognostic information beyond plaque characteristics. An increased pressure gradient across a lesion is associated with increased axial tensile stress, flow disturbances and ESS heterogeneity; this unfavorable hemodynamic environment can accelerate atherosclerotic evolution, leading to plaque destabilization and future events(18,19).The findings of the present analysis provide evidence of the value of 3D-QCAÀderived hemodynamic indexes in identifying vulnerable plaques (Supplemental Figure 3). Software have been developed that enable real-time computation of the fractional flow reserve from 3D-QCA, which could be used in future studies to enhance the efficacy of intravascular imaging in detecting plaques prone to progress and cause events (20). Moreover, the present analysis also underscore the potential value of plaque morphology and physiology (i.e., ESS distribution or pressure drop across a lesion) in stratifying cardiovascular risk. The models that are currently available to identify high-risk patients rely either on patient demographics or on the combination of clinical and imaging biomarkers and they have modest predictive accuracy (21). The patient-level analysis of our study showed that the subjects with high-risk plaques and an unfavorable local hemodynamic environment had a high event rate during follow-up. Further research is needed to examine the potential value of noninvasive or invasive assessment of plaque pathology (i.e., plaque burden and composition) and physiology in identifying patients at risk who would benefit from emerging therapies that target atherosclerosis. STUDY LIMITATIONS. A significant limitation of the present analysis was that only 48% of the lipid-rich lesions that caused MACE-R were suitable for inclusion. This might have introduced selection bias and resulted in a small sample size and events that did not allow us to accurately quantify the additive value of hemodynamic variables over VH-IVUSÀderived plaque characteristics in predicting MACE-R. Therefore, the reported results should be interpreted with caution and require further confirmation in future large-scale studies. In addition, in some of the angiograms from the PROSPECT study, the pixel size was not available; thus, vessel reconstruction relied on a manual calibration that could affect the accuracy of 3D-QCA modeling. Moreover, we performed steady flow simulation, which assumed that blood was a Newtonian fluid, and we did not include side branches in the 3D-QCA models. Steady flow simulation can accurately predict time-averaged ESS in pulsatile simulations (22). Conversely, a Newtonian assumption might not accurately approximate blood behavior, especially in diseased segments where more regions of slow flow are expected (23). In addition, the incorporation of the side branches in the 3D models was expected to enable more accurate assessment of the ESS distribution; however, a recent study showed that incorporation of the side branches into the 3D vessel geometry only marginally improved the accuracy of the ESS in predicting plaque evolution (24). Complex simulation, especially in complex geometries, is time consuming and cannot be performed in the catheterization laboratory. With the proposed approach, ESS, and especially, the pressure drop across a lesion, can be computed fast in single-vessel geometries. Currently, QCA reconstruction and blood flow simulation takes approximately 15 min; however, developments in software design and advances in computer technology are expected to s5 in IBIS 4 [Volcano Corp., Rancho Cordova, California]; VH analysis from these 2 systems might provide different estimations for plaque composition and phenotype. In addition, follow-up coronary angiography and revascularization because of disease progression on angiography was performed only in the IBIS 4 study, whereas the follow-up period (median 3.4 years in the PROSPECT and 5 years in the IBIS-4) was different in the 2 studies. However, it is reassuring that our findings were similar when analysis was restricted to MACE or to the first 3.4 years of follow-up (Supplemental Figure 4). Finally, the number of the events reported in this analysis was relatively small, and most of the events were unstable or progressive angina and not hard clinical endpoints (death, myocardial infarction). However, we must acknowledge that in all the prospective multivessel intravascular imaging studies of coronary atherosclerosis, the incidence of hard endpoints is low (1À3). In addition, the clinical endpoints of this study were similar to the endpoints of the recently completed Lipid Rich Plaque study and of ongoing studies of coronary atherosclerosis (PROS-PECT II [PROSPECT II & PROSPECT ABSORB-An Integrated Natural History Study and Randomized Trial. (P2)]; NCT02171065; PREVENT [The Preventive Coronary Intervention on Stenosis With Functionally Insignificant Vulnerable Plaque]; NCT02316886; COMBINE [Optical Coherence Tomography Morphologic and Fractional Flow Reserve Assessment in Diabetes Mellitus Patients]; NCT02989740) that are expected to provide additional data and the substrate to prove the concept introduced in this study.CONCLUSIONS In the present analysis of the PROSPECT and IBIS 4 studies, hemodynamic indexes estimated from 3D-QCA models provided additional prognostic information to VH-IVUSÀderived variables and enabled more accurate detection of nonflow limiting lesions that were likely to progress and cause events. Prospective studies are needed to confirm these findings and examine the efficacy of intravascular imaging and 3D-QCA-derived variables in detecting high-risk lesions and patients who may benefit from preemptive focal or systemic treatment of atherosclerosis.

KEY WORDS quantitative coronary angiography, shear stress, vulnerable plaque APPENDIX For an expanded Methods section and supplemental tables and figures, please see the online version of this paper. of Identifying Vulnerable Plaque Remains Alive* Habib Samady, MD, a Joo Myung Lee, MD, MPH, PHD a,b T he 2 major arguments against pursuing detection of vulnerable plaques are as follows: 1) it is the patient as a whole who is vulnerable to an acute coronary event and not the individual plaque; and 2) even if one could identify characteristics of plaques that are likely to be vulnerable to rapidly progress, rupture, or erode, the prevalence of such plaques is likely too low to have clinical value. For the proponents of vulnerable plaque detection, however, the rebuttal to the first argument is that the concept of the vulnerable plaque is not mutually exclusive with that of a vulnerable patient. It is clear that the most likely host of a vulnerable plaque is a vulnerable patient. Indeed, any ultimate clinical evaluation of a potential vulnerable plaque should be performed in a high-risk population further enriched by biomics, including genomics, transcriptionomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and lipidomics, as well as inflammatory and oxidative stress biomarkers, among others. The second argument related to low prevalence of vulnerable plaque, even in enriched nonculprit vessels of patients with acute coronary syndrome(1-3), has been rebutted by the observation that vessel and plaque biomechanics play an important role in further enriching coronary plaque phenotyping (4-6). Building on extensive basic and translational underpinnings, initial clinical studies in patients with mild coronary atherosclerosis showed that coronary segments with low endothelial shear stress (ESS) or wall shear stress (WSS) are associated with plaque progression (7). Interestingly, there has been controversy over the prognostic value of segments with high WSS, with some observations showing transformation of high WSS segments into a vulnerable phenotype

FIGREF200.text: porated into clinically relevant investigations. In this issue of iJACC, Bourantas et al. (17) report on their case-control study using the PROSPECT (Providing Regional Observations to Study Predictors of Events in the Coronary Tree) and IBIS-4 (Integrated Biomarker Imaging Study-4) datasets to investigate the prognostic value of anatomic and biomechanical coronary plaque features of patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). They evaluated several anatomic plaque features, including minimal luminal area (MLA), plaque burden (PB), and the presence of thick cap fibroatheroma assessed by virtual histology intravascular ultrasound (VH-IVUS); they also evaluated 3D-QCA-derived minimal luminal diameter (MLD), percent diameter stenosis (%DS), and ESS (or WSS). The authors make several very interesting observations (17). The patient-level analysis showed that MLA, PB, MLD, %DS, and the maximum ESS were predictors of the primary endpoint, MACE plus revascularization (MACE-R). They further inform the controversy regarding the prognostic value of low versus high ESS by showing that patients who had lipid-rich plaques with $2 high-risk plaque characteristics who were exposed to high ESS (>4.95 Pa) had a worse prognosis than those with high-risk plaques exposed to low ESS. The results also showed that a resting pressure gradient >2.31 mm Hg across lesions provides additional prognostic information to plaque morphology in indicating that patients with lesions with $2 high-risk plaque characteristics or MLA #4 mm 2 and PB $70%. The lesion-level findings of Bourantas et al. (17) are largely consistent with their patient-level analysis. The univariable predictors of MACE-R included VH-IVUS-derived variable lesion length, MLA and PB, 3D-QCA-derived MLD and %DS, and the hemodynamic variables of maximum ESS value and pressure drop across the lesion. Multivariable analysis revealed that PB and maximum ESS were independent predictors of MACE-R lesions, and maximum ESS was the only independent predictor of MACE-R when the MLA was entered in the multivariate model. In addition, the best ESS cutoff for predicting MACE-R lesions was 4.95 Pa.

FIGREF201.text: low ESS. Finally, the maximum lesion ESS had additive value in predicting MACE-R over the established VH-IVUS-derived high-risk plaque characteristics. There are several unique features of this investigation (17). First, the nonculprit target lesions of patients with ACS were very mild, non-flow-limiting with a median DS of 26% and a modest pressure gradient of 1.95 mm Hg. Second, the simplified 3D-QCA computational fluid dynamic (CFD) methodology, using steady flow boundary conditions and not accounting for side branches, enables faster CFD simulation. Third, the resting pressure gradient has incremental prognostic value over anatomic plaque severity and plaque characteristic features. Fourth, and importantly, unlike the authors' previous findings (5), they found in the current study that maximum WSS (>4.95 Pa), and not the minimum ESS, was an independent predictor of MACE (cardiac death, myocardial infarction, or revascularization due to unstable angina) or MACE-R (cardiac death, myocardial infarction, or revascularization due to unstable angina or evidence of angiographic progression base on diameter stenosis) at 5 years.

FIGREF202.text: Compact fibrosis by itself is not arrhythmogenic because electrical propagation through the scar is impossible, whereas it may give rise to re-entrant circuits. To initiate the re-entrant circuit, unidirectional conduction block in some part of the circuit is a pre-requisite. Furthermore, to sustain the re-entrant circuit, the length of this circuit needs to be long enough to enable tissue in each part of the circuit to restore its excitability in order to conduct the next impulse. Unexcitable regions caused by infarction in the human heart may have a circumference of that length. Furthermore, activation delay has also been observed in normal myocardium at sites where an activation front proceeds from a small strand into a larger structure. In these cases, the activation delay was based on the so-called source-sink mismatch,i.e., a delay caused by the difference between the current supply of the small source and the current requirement of the large sink, thus providing an alternative explanation of slow conduction in infarcted areas where encapsulated myocyte bundles interconnect. De Bakker et al. (8) elegantly demonstrated that surviving myocardial fibers in the chronic healed phase of myocardial infarction are encapsulated by fibrous tissue. In these interconnected bundles of myocardial fibers, slow conduction perpendicular to the fiber direction proceeds along complex pathways with a "zigzag" pattern characterized by branching and merging of surviving myocardial fibers that are encapsulated by collagenous strands of the infarct scar. Diffuse fibrosis means that collagen is interspersed among myocardial fibers. This reduces gap junction connections between myocytes, isolates myocytes from each other, and thereby , C. et al. J Am Coll Cardiol Img. 2020;13(10):2223-38.

FIGREF203.text: (9). Second, fibrosis promotes triggers. Patchy and severe interstitial fibrosis creates strands of myocytes that increase the possibility that a premature ventricular complex is generated and propagates into the surrounding tissue(10). Third, myofibroblasts have a direct pro-arrhythmic effect on myocyte electrophysiological properties(11). By expressing connexins and gap junctions between myofibroblasts and myocytes, the cells are coupled electrically, and resting potential is slightly depolarized. Hence, the threshold for spontaneous afterdepolarization is reduced and triggers emerge. Lastly, paracrine factors secreted by myofibroblasts further promote a pro-arrhythmic effect on myocytes(12).The different patterns of myocardial fibrosis (i.e. compact, patchy, interstitial, and diffuse) are involved in various electrophysiological mechanisms to generate ventricular arrhythmia under different predisposing conditions. Different types of tissue remodeling (i.e., replacement fibrosis or reactive interstitial fibrosis) have implications in both therapies and imaging visualization of fibrosis. Replacement fibrosis occurs after cell damage, is responsible for maintaining the structural integrity of the heart, and mainly consists of type I collagen. Replacement

In a prospective multicenter study of patients after myocardial infarction, global longitudinal strain by echocardiography predicted arrhythmic events(17).SINGLE-PHOTON EMISSION TOMOGRAPHY AND POSITRON EMISSION TOMOGRAPHY. The neurohumoral activation plays a central role in the failing heart. Myocardial infarction not only results in the loss of contractile myocardium but also alters the sympathetic response of the myocardium to catecholamines. These regional heterogeneities of the sympathetic innervation create a substrate that is vulnerable to arrhythmic death (18). Targeting the cardiac sympathetic innervation using molecular nuclear imaging has become an emerging approach to visualize the arrhythmogenic substrate. FIGREF206.text: Compared with VT from transient abnormal automaticity caused by ischemia or post-ischemic reperfusion(24), triggered activity and re-entry are the underlying mechanisms in scarred myocardium in the setting of chronic IHD(20,24). Besides stress perfusion CMR, nuclear perfusion imaging using technetium-99m in SPECT, or rubidium-82, 15Olabeled water or 13N-ammonia in PET has the ability to assess ischemia and myocardial scars. In an observational cohort of 4,865 patients with IHD and LVEF >35%, the extent of stress myocardial perfusion imaging defects was associated with an increased risk of SCD(25). On the other hand, myocardial scarring by PET (and not ischemia) was associated with appropriate ICD shocks and SCD(26). Furthermore, PET has the ability to noninvasively assess the coronary flow reserve (CFR), and CFR appears to be an independent predictor of mortality in patients with IHD (27)(Figure 1). Myocardial viability (F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose PET)-guided coronary revascularization may improve outcome in patients with IHD (27). Future clinical trials need to establish specific thresholds of SPECT perfusion defects and CFR that can be used toward specific therapy for the prevention of SCD in IHD. COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY. Myocardial delayed enhancement (MDE) in computed tomographic (CT) imaging has been demonstrated to accurately display scar tissue compared with pathological specimens and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE)

FIGREF207.text: assesses cardiac morphology and function at high accuracy and reproducibility. Furthermore, CMR offers myocardial tissue characterization and visualization of fibrosis, which may offer novel risk stratification of SCD. These features include LVEF,

FIGREF208.text: CMR figure, a patient is presented with ventricular tachycardia, ischemic heart disease, and a history of myocardial infarction of the left anterior descending coronary artery and right coronary artery. Cardiac magnetic resonance shows a dilated left ventricle, severely impaired left ventricular ejection fraction, and extended transmural late gadolinium enhancement in short-axis images of the (A) basal slice, (B) midventricular slice, and 4-chamber view in the vessel distribution territory of the left anterior descending artery (red arrows) and RCA (blue arrows). (D) Furthermore, native T1 mapping shows a prolonged time with 1,108 ms in the septum. This results in a high gadolinium concentration in the interstitial space, shortened local T1 relaxation time, and signal enhancement on CMR images. Later in time, as the necrotic myocardium becomes replaced by a fibrotic scar and the interstitial space further expands, marked gadolinium concentration and signal enhancement are observed on LGE imaging. LGE has demonstrated a strong association with serious ventricular arrhythmia in patients with left ventricular dysfunction incremental to LVEF (36). As a consequence, the issue has been raised whether: 1) patients with LGE would benefit from primary prevention ICD irrespective of LVEF and what extent, distribution, location, and pattern is predictive of arrhythmias; and 2) whether ICD implantation may be avoided in patients without LGE despite reduced LVEF.

FIGREF210.text: GUIDE (Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance-GUIDEd Management of Mild to Moderate Left Ventricular Systolic Dysfunction) trial. In this ongoing prospective, multicenter randomized controlled trial, mild to moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction will be enrolled to address the association of myocardial fibrosis with the risk of lifethreatening ventricular arrhythmias in patients with optimized heart failure therapy (82). It could be speculated that CMR assessment may be beneficial in the detection of clinical responders to GDMTs in atrisk heart failure populations. Potentially, some patients who respond to GDMTs with resultant improvement of LVEF will have correspondingly reduced risk of SCD and obviate the need for an ICD. It also may be beneficial in patients with a questionable need for routine reimplantation of ICD at generator exchange (e.g., low burden of appropriate ICD firing and/or interval improvement of left ventricular function from GDMTs), the use of CMR scar burden, dynamic monitoring of fibrosis progression, or novel PET assessment of sympathetic activity; it may possibly offer an innovative method to identify those who do not benefit from reimplantation. Finally, the conventional definition of SCD is biased by the lack of autopsy confirmation in modern clinical practice. Many deaths labelled as SCD in outcome studies were indeed nonarrhythmic in nature (83).

Although AVC quantification is well established in determining AS severity with discordant Doppler echocardiography findings, there is a significant variation in AVC burden between patients for any degree of hemodynamic obstruction. Our findings expound the limitations of quantifying AVC burden without considering valvular distribution, and although because of reproducibility cohort size we cannot exclude the possibility of observer-dependent bias affecting our findings, our results suggest that an assessment of AVC distribution may prove complementary to AVC quantification when considering the link between AVC load and both uncertain hemodynamic severity and atypical disease progression. Their role should now be evaluated in terms of clinical decision making and outcome. William S. Jenkins, MD, PhD Louis Simard, BSc Marie-Annick Clavel, DVM, PhD Thomas A. Foley, MD Philip A. Our institutional review board approved the study and waived informed consent. Overall, 18% of TTEs had a new or worsening finding to potentially explain syncope, with the most common etiologies being cardiomyopathy/ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation substrate (37%)and signs of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (33%) (Figure 1A).

FIGREF227.text: 1B displays the frequency of TTE findings to potentially explain syncope as a function of the presence of a prior TTE and prior TTE findings. Adjusting for age, sex, race, and inpatient status, there was no significant difference in new findings to potentially explain syncope when comparing those without a prior TTE to those with a prior normal TTE (odds ratio: 0.96; 95% confidence interval: 0.72 to 1.30; p ¼ 0.78). There was also no difference based on the time interval (<1, 1 to 5, >5 years) between the index and prior TTE. As expected, those with a prior abnormal TTE were more likely to have new or worsening findings to potentially explain syncope (odds ratio: 1.81; 95% confidence interval: 1.16 to 2.83; p ¼ 0.009), with the driving factor being worsening of findings seen on the prior TTE.

Anderson-Fabry disease (AFD) cardiomyopathy is characterized by glycosphingolipid (Gb3) storage in all cellular components, with consequent left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). Gb3 accumulation also involves atrial myocytes (1), ultimately leading to left atrial (LA) enlargement and reduced atrial compliance. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) plays an important role in the assessment of the severity of Fabry cardiomyopathy. CMR feature tracking (CMR-FT) specifically allows the assessment of myocardial strain from cine images (2).

FIGREF235.text: The APPROACH (Alberta Provincial Project for Outcome Assessment in Coronary Heart Disease)-estimated fractional flow reserve derived from coronary computed tomography angiography (APPROACH FFRCT ) score is calculated by first assessing the FFR CT model to determine if the distal vessel is positive (#0.80). Then, the location at which the vessel transitions to FFR CT #0.80 is determined, and finally, the ischemic myocardial burden is estimated distal to this point using the APPROACH scoring matrix.(A) A gray zone-positive FFR CT in the distal left anterior descending artery (LAD). (B, C) The transition point for FFR CT #0.80 is in the distal vessel with an estimated ischemic myocardial burden at 13.75%. (D-F) Incremental diagnostic performance of combined FFR CT and APPROACH FFRCT compared with FFR CT alone. AUC ¼ area under the receiver-operating characteristic curve; LCx ¼ left circumflex artery; LD ¼ left dominant; OM ¼ obtuse marginal; PDA ¼ posterior descending artery; RCA ¼ right coronary artery; RD ¼ right dominant. 95% CI: 0.48 to 0.74]; p ¼ 0.05) with no benefit in vessels with FFR CT values <0.70

FIGREF236.text: The diagnostic reclassification performance was also significantly improved when APPROACH FFRCT was added to FFR CT (IDI: 0.04; p ¼ 0.009), with the largest improvement observed in vessels with gray-zone FFR CT values (IDI 0.10; p ¼ 0.009). A similar incremental benefit was observed on a per-patient analysis (data not shown). In vessels with FFR CT #0.80, the use of the FFR CT model to estimate the ischemic myocardial burden is a simple, rapid, and reproducible technique, which provides improved diagnostic discrimination of vessel-specific ischemia over FFR CT alone, particularly at FFR CT values in the gray zone between 0.7 and 0.8. As a stand-alone clinical tool, the location at which FFR CT values should be read is unclear, especially because there is typically a gradual decline of FFR CT values along the course of even normal coronary arteries (3). The majority of clinical studies have thus far applied the most distal FFR CT value in guiding clinical decisions (3). This potentially overestimates the hemodynamic significance of coronary artery lesions . Our results suggest that with gray-zone FFR CT values or FFR CT values that only decrease below the ischemic threshold in the distal vessel, the integration of CT-derived ischemic myocardial burden using the APPROACH FFRCT score may assist in the interpretation of FFR CT in real-world practice. Myocardial mass is a key determinant for modeling FFR CT ; however, it is only used to derive total coronary flow and global baseline resistance (4). These global measures of coronary flow and resistance are then distributed along the coronary tree in relation to vessel size (4). Therefore, although myocardial mass is an input in the modeling of FFR CT , the FFR CT value on the coronary geometry is not influenced by the degree of fractional myocardial mass subtended.

However, quantification of right ventriculoarterial coupling with pulmonary arterial elastance (Ea) as an index of RV afterload and RV end-systolic elastance (Ees) as an index of RV contractibility may provide a more comprehensive evaluation of RV adaptation to PH (1). CMR ¼ cardiac magnetic resonance. extracellular matrix (ECM)(2). In this study, wecombined macroscopic myocardial structure by CMR, whole biopsy collagen volume fraction (CVF%) by 2D light microcopy, and tissue composition by high-resolution confocal microscopy. The study was approved by the ethics committee of the U.K. National Research Ethics Service (07/H0715/101). The study conformed to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki, and all subjects gave written informed consent. Nine patients with severe aortic stenosis scheduled for surgical aortic valve replacement (54% male; median age 65 [58 to 80] years; indexed aortic valve area 0.4 AE 0.04 cm 2 ) underwent CMR for left ventricular (LV) structure, function, and ECV% quantification (3). Two intraoperative myocardial biopsy samples were obtained for each patient by Tru-Cut needle biopsy from the basal LV septum. One biopsy specimen was fixed in formaldehyde, paraffin embedded, and stained with Picrosirius red for CVF% quantification (w5 mm 2 per sample). The second biopsy specimen was embedded in optimum cutting-temperature compound (Tissue-Tek, Sakura Finetek USA, Torrance, California) and snap frozen (3). Myocytes were labeled with a rabbit anti-dystrophin antibody, nonmyocytes with a mouse monoclonal anti-Vimentin antibody, and ECM and cell membranes with wheat germ agglutinin-tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate(2). Sections were imaged with confocal laser-scanning microscopy (4) and analyzed by using custom ImageJ plug-ins (w6.5 mm 3 per sample).

FIGREF240.text: (p ¼ 0.40) or CMR parameters of LV size (enddiastolic volume/end-systolic volume), LV ejection fraction, or ECV%. CVF% correlated with N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (rho ¼ 0.85; p ¼ 0.003) and high-sensitivity troponin T (rho ¼ 0.78; p ¼ 0.03) but not ECV%. layered information on structure, function, tissue characterization, and biomarkers is needed. CMR captures hypertrophy by quantifying overall mass and then dichotomizing the myocardium into cellular and extracellular compartments. Histology (2D or confocal) identifies different tissues better than CMR but within a very limited sampling area (confocal <0.007 ml/CVF% ¼ 0.01 ml/CMR >100 ml) and only reports ratios of tissue/cell subtypes and their relative expansion. Hence, the lack of association between CMR and histology underscores that they ultimately offer complementary insights at vastly different dimensions. Although the approaches have limitations related to sampling (scalability/size/ location), process (vasodilatation/intramyocardial and blood pool not captured), and staining, they represent an advance in visualization and combined insight. For the clinical and especially the imaging cardiologist, our data also serve as a reminder of the importance of nonmyocytes (especially endothelial cells and fibroblasts), which despite being much smaller than cardiomyocytes, are more numerous (5) and occupy 10% to 15% of the LV myocardium.

FIGREF243.text: . Our group previously published data providing prognostic and hemodynamic validation for the ASE/ EACVI algorithms and the E/é ratio following a first myocardial infarction (MI)(3,4). We re-analyzed our data to determine if significant DD (grade 2/3) assessed using the combined algorithm had a robust correlation with clinical outcomes and invasively measured LVFP.The study cohort for the prognostic study con-sisted of 419 patients with MI who underwent echocardiography the day after admission and were followed up for a median of 24 months. The primary endpoint was a composite of recurrent MI, heart failure, and death (major adverse cardiovascular event(s) [MACE]). The study cohort for the hemodynamic study consisted of 120 patients with nonÀSTsegment elevation MI who underwent either simultaneous (n ¼ 30) or same day (n ¼ 90) cardiac catheterization and echocardiography. The correlation between significant DD assessed with the combined algorithm and invasively measured left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) was analyzed (LVEDP $15 mm Hg was considered elevated). For the current re-analysis, all patients were re-graded for DD based on the combined algorithm, with patients with $3 criteria of septal é <7 cm/s, septal E/é >15, tricuspid regurgitation velocity (TRV) >2.8 m/s, and left atrial volume index >34 ml/m 2 categorized as having significant DD. Patients with 2 and 2 of both criteria were further classified with pulmonary venous inflow data (systolic (S) to diastolic (D) ratio ratio <1.0 regarded as evidence of significant DD). After further exclusions for unavailability of TRV, the final cohorts included 277 and 67 patients in the prognostic and hemodynamic studies, respectively.

FIGREF244.text: ROC curves for septal and average E/é for predicting elevated LVEDP showed similar accuracy with areas under the curve of 0.72 and 0.73, respectively (both p < 0.001)(4).The main findings of the re-analysis of our previously published data were that significant DD assessed using the novel combined algorithm: 1) was an independent predictor of clinical outcomes; and 2) detected elevated LVEDP with a high specificity and positive predictive value. These results were consistent with the results of previously published studies and were not unexpected because the novel com-bined algorithm was derived by combining the 2 ASE/ EACVI algorithms. The limitation of the combined algorithm was that the frequent unavailability of TRV limited the application of the algorithm. We did not perform a direct comparison of the combined algorithm with the ASE/EACVI algorithms primarily because the ASE/EACVI algorithms remain the preferred approach in our laboratories based on evidence from a large body of hemodynamic and prognostic validations in a variety of clinical settings. The data presented here had some limitations. Preexisting data were re-analyzed for this research. Only subjects with MI were included, and further validation in other patient subsets is needed. For patients with indeterminate diastolic function using the combined algorithm, other data that could have refined the assessment of DD (including left atrial strain or global longitudinal strain) were not routinely available. Measurements of mean left atrial pressure, the ideal measure of left atrial pressure, were not available. Finally, longer term follow-up in larger cohorts would be desirable. THE AUTHORS REPLY: I read with interest the letter by Dr. Prasad and colleagues. The investigators draw reasonable conclusions from the post hoc analysis of previously acquired data. Because of the inclusion of similar echo-Doppler parameters, the performance of the combined algorithm was similar to the main guidelines, with only a 5% difference in significant diastolic dysfunction (DD) grading (1). Although limitations were acknowledged, a few points are worth emphasis. The overall attempt in looking at the accuracy of DD algorithms was hampered by the low feasibility of tricuspid regurgitation (TR) jet acquisition, at only 55% in the hemodynamic study and 66% in the prognostic study. This limitation was not unique to the work by Dr. Prasad andcolleagues, and stemmed from the attempt to apply the guidelines to retrospectively acquired data. The guidelines were also applied to several prospective studies that did not use saline or contrast agents to enhance the TR jet when the objective was to study diastolic function.The investigators presented the results in all patients, but it is important to assess accuracy based on left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction (EF) and the presence or absence of LV segmental abnormalities.

FIGREF245.text: H. Marwick, MBBS, PHD, MPH, Deputy Editor, Y. Chandrashekhar, MD, Editor-in-Chief A trial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) share common risk factors, and symptoms, they potentiate each other, and together contribute to poor prognosis (1). Both conditions are increasing in prevalence with population aging. They are linked by left ventricular (LV) and left atrial (LA) dysfunction, but this has been a problem in addressing their pathophysiology and perhaps even in defining a treatment, because these phenomena have conventionally been difficult to measure. LA volume and function have been considered important for diastolic evaluation (2), and both predict future AF, both overt (3) and silent (4). Assessment of LA function using classical techniques such as pulmonary venous and transmitral flow measurements is less feasible and less widely adopted.

FIGREF246.text: In a study of 257 patients following myocardial infarction, Kim et al. (6) documented a twofold difference in LARS in patients with diastolic dysfunction and those without. LARS was significantly impaired even in patients with mild dysfunction, regardless of whether echocardiographic or CMR methods were used. Importantly, impaired LARS was associated with AF in follow-up. As pointed out by the accompanying editorial, the work by Kim et al. (6) advances the field by independent validation of echocardiographic methods by CMR, the use of vendor-agnostic software, and the link between diastolic dysfunction, AF, and heart failure.These findings were complemented by Park et al. (12), whose study of 4,312 consecutive patients with acute HF, 16% of whom developed new onset AF over follow-up. Patients with reduced LARS (#18%) had a 60% increment of hazard of new-onset AF, independent of age, hypertension, LA size, HFpEF, and the absence of beta blockade. Although the accompanying editorial expressed reservations about the uptake of the resulting HAS-BAP (hypertension, age, PALS, no Beta-blocker prescription at discharge, atrial volume index, HFpEF (range, 0-6)) score, the ability to identify a high-risk group opens intriguing possibilities. Strain measurements open another interesting avenues of research in the AF-embolic events linkage: could they denote an "atrial myopathy" that could mediate blood stasis and risk thromboembolism events independent of AF (13,14)? LA strain abnormalities are early signs of chamber dysfunction and remodeling and correlate with local structural changes like regional fibrosis (15). Whether through AF or without it, LA strain seems to predict adverse events robustly and becomes a useable marker in clinical practice. The pathophysiology of cardiac aging underlies the most common and increasing cardiac diseases, AF and HFpEF. Measurement of LV global longitudinal strain, already a sensitive marker of subclinical LV dysfunction (16), is now being strengthened by a strain measurement for atrial dysfunction. The 2 measurements provide an opportunity for better characterization of the complexities of diastolic dysfunction where the current pillars of LA volume, transmitral flow, e 0 , and E/e 0 leave many situations of

TABREF15.text: Making a Splash Stress Lung Ultrasound and the Rising Tide of Lung Water* Sharon L. Mulvagh, MD, a Omid Kiamanesh, MD b L ung ultrasound (LUS) is making a splash, and it is time for cardiologists to dive in. Congestion is a common, yet often challenging-to-diagnose finding in heart failure. It is a strong predictor of poor cardiovascular outcomes, including hospitalization and death. Our current approach to diagnosing congestion by using symptoms and late signs is insensitive and delayed. We know that earlier in the course of clinical congestion, a cascade of events initiates with a rise in left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic pressure and results in pulmonary congestion. However, until very recently, we have lacked a practical, noninvasive, radiation-free tool to assess this early rise of lung water. Enter lung ultrasonography! LUS is more accurate than chest auscultation and radiographs to detect pulmonary edema (1) and can predict mortality after hospital discharge (2). LUS interpretation is based on artifacts produced by normal and abnormal lung. Fluid-filled lung interstitium produces vertical hyperechoic artifacts called B-lines that correlate with pulmonary congestion. B-lines may be quantified by count (sum of Blines) or score ($3 B-lines is "positive") per zone examined. Quantifying B-lines provides a graded estimate of pulmonary congestion; #2 may be normal, whereas >2 is abnormal, and coalescent B-lines are severely abnormal. A novel approach of combining LUS with stress echocardiography can detect an increase in pulmonary congestion in response to exercise (3). Indeed, stress LUS to detect pulmonary congestion is analogous to inducing regional wall motion abnormalities during stress echocardiography to detect ischemia. However, until now, stress LUS has shown no prognostic value and has been poorly used compared with stress echocardiography. In this issue of iJACC, Scali et al. (4) report on their experience using LUS to detect pulmonary congestion during stress echocardiography to predict death and nonfatal myocardial infarction. This prespecified interim analysis of The International Stress Echo Study in Ischemic and Non-ischemic Heart Disease (Stress Echo 2020) included 2,145 consecutive adult patients referred for stress echocardiography to evaluate coronary artery disease and heart failure. They excluded patients with noncardiac diseases that produce B-lines, such as interstitial lung disease and pneumonia. Although the population was representative, information regarding medication use, noncardiac comorbidities, and interventions was lacking. The patients underwent stress LUS combined with stress echocardiography. B-lines were counted at rest and after stress using a simplified 4-zone protocol (Figure 1). Patients were grouped according to the peak number of stress B-lines, scored from 0 to 40. Severe stress B-lines ($10) were observed in 119 patients and associated with increased age, comorbidities, and measures of poor cardiac function, including stress-induced regional wall motion abnormalities, exercise-induced B-lines, lower LV contractile reserve, lower coronary flow velocity reserve, and abnormal heart rate reserve. They were also associated with poorer anatomic indices, including moderate or greater mitral regurgitation, and multivessel coronary artery disease. Not surprisingly, severe stress B-lines were associated with a higher risk of death and nonfatal myocardial infarction by univariate (hazard ratio: 8.27; 95% confidence interval: 4.17 to 16.40; p < 0.01) and multivariate (hazard ratio: 3.54; 95% confidence interval: 1.47 to 8.69; p < 0.01) analyses at a median follow-up of 15 months. Importantly, severe stress B-lines improved risk reclassification and incrementally improved the prediction of death and nonfatal myocardial infarction. This study (4) adds to growing evidence for the detection of pulmonary congestion by LUS in patients with heart failure. Pulmonary congestion is quickly and reliably detected by LUS to predict poorer outcomes (5). LUS can also detect changes in pulmonary congestion in response to therapy, which is associated with improved outcomes. Importantly, LUS has incremental prognostic value beyond clinical examination to predict heart failure rehospitalization and death. Scali et al. (3) previously applied LUS to stress testing and correlated exercise-induced B-lines with a poorer B-type natriuretic peptide level, peak oxygen uptake, and clinical outcome in ambulatory patients with heart failure with decreased LV systolic function. The current study builds on their findings by using a large and representative international cohort of patients and a simplified 4-zone protocol to increase the power, generalizability, and feasibility of using stress LUS to predict outcomes. The study by Scali et al. (4) has several limitations. First, the method of stress was suboptimal and not uniform. Only one-half of the patients were exercised, which is the preferred method to assess a hemodynamic response. The other half received a vasodilator, which produces a different hemodynamic profile that is better suited to detect ischemia. Second, it is unsurprising that severe stress B-lines are associated with poorer outcomes. However, this definition is arbitrary and not standardized. The incremental value of severe stress Blines should be compared against a similar grade of functional indices, such as severe inducible wall motion abnormalities and severe decline in LV function. Third, the prognostic value of exerciseinduced B-lines should be normalized for the presence of rest B-lines to conclude that stress LUS provides an incremental benefit over rest LUS. Fourth, there is no comparison of stress B-lines with clinically useful indices of heart failure, such as the ratio between early mitral inflow velocity and mitral annular early diastolic velocity, B-type natriuretic peptide levels, and peak oxygen uptake. Fifth, treatment interventions are not reported and could have affected the primary outcome. We commend Scali et al. Their essential work helps LUS evolve from a point-of-care test into a diagnostic technique. In this study (4), they show that stress LUS can be standardized and operationalized across multinational centers with excellent interobserver reliability using a highly feasible (100%) and reproducible 4-zone protocol. Stress LUS can be performed with the same ultrasound probe as cardiac imaging, uses neighboring scanning zones, and is not affected by tachycardia or respiratory motion. Furthermore, stress LUS does not interfere with the performance of stress echocardiography. Because pulmonary congestion persists into recovery, stress LUS images can be acquired following stress echocardiography, similar to the acquisition of diastolic stress testing parameters. With this foundational study, the authors prove that stress LUS is reliable, accurate, and useful. In doing so, they lay the groundwork for this field to advance. The next generation of studies using stress LUS will include standardized reporting and a large number of patients to define the optimal methods, cutoffs, and application of this technique (6). These studies should capitalize on the strengths of stress LUS to determine how it can improve our standard methods of assessment. For example, can stress LUS identify patients with latent diastolic dysfunction by the development of pulmonary congestion in response to exercise? Does the number of exerciseinduced B-lines have an incremental value beyond their mere presence? Can the dynamic assessment of B-lines allow us to tailor heart failure therapies such as medications, mechanical circulatory support, and transcatheter mitral valve interventions? Stress Echo 2020 will answer some of these questions and likely generate many more

MULTIVARIATE ASSOCIATIONS, MODEL DISCRIMINATION, AND RISK RECLASSIFICATION IMPROVEMENT. For the primary outcome, age, sex, history of diabetes, history of MI, history of CHF, and LVEF were chosen by the forward selection algorithm to form the baseline clinical multivariate model (À2 log likelihood ¼ 1,081) (Table 3, clinical model). Adjusted for the effects of the covariates in the clinical model and for each other, presence of ischemia (HR: 2.63; 95% CI: 1.68 to 4.14; p < 0.001) and LGE (HR: 1.86; 95% CI: 1.05 to 3.29; p ¼ 0.03) maintained significant associations with the primary outcome. Presence of ischemia and presence of LGE independently improved this clinical model for the primary outcome when they were separately added (À2 log likelihood ¼ 1,055 and 1,069 for ischemia and LGE, respectively; p < 0.001 for both) or when both were added (À2 log likelihood ¼ 1,051; p<0.001) to the model. The addition of ischemia and LGE to the clinical model for the primary outcome also improved the model discrimination (Harrell's C statistic ¼ 0.715 to 0.765; p ¼ 0.02).

TABREF58.text: In this retrospective cohort of patients with reduced LVEF referred to stress CMR for suspicion of CAD, we observed that stress CMR-detected myocardial ischemia and LGE provided incremental value to a clinical model for hard cardiovascular outcomes.Furthermore, in this cohort with evidence of cardiomyopathy, those with neither CMR ischemia nor infarct by LGE constituted a low-risk group with an annualized hard event rate of 1.1%. of stress CMR, have mostly included LVEF with median or mean in the normal range. In a metaanalysis of 19 studies and 11,636 patients with known or suspected CAD undergoing stress CMR, Lipinski et al. (8) reported an annualized hard outcome (cardiovascular death or nonfatal MI) rate of 4.9% and 0.8% for positive versus negative ischemia and 4.6% and 1.4% for positive versus negative LGE at median follow-up of 25 months. Mean LVEF for the included studies, however, ranged between 55% and 67%. Few studies have examined the prognostic impact of stress CMR in a population with impaired LVEF. Husser et al. (24) reported on 391 patients with reduced LVEF (mean 39%) undergoing stress CMR. At median follow-up of 1.8 years, presence of perfusion defect, but not LGE, was associated with major cardiovascular events. However, that study was limited by its relatively short follow-up duration and lack of adjustment for history of heart failure and LVEF. Our study significantly expands upon prior results and demonstrated that at median follow-up of 5.0 years, independent of LVEF, CMR-detected myocardial ischemia and LGE provided incremental prognostic value to a clinical model for cardiovascular outcomes. In patients with heart failure, particularly in those with depressed LVEF, assessment of etiology is of paramount importance in determining prognosis and treatment. Studies have previously demonstrated that both the presence and extent of coronary disease are predictive of long-term mortality in patients with cardiomyopathy (25,26). Although pharmacologicalFIGURE 4 Invasive Coronary Angiography and Revascularization at 90 Days Referred to Coronary Angiography Within 90 Days Coronary Revascularization Within 90 Days if Referred to Coronary Angiography Referral to invasive angiography at 90 days, with corresponding percentage of patients undergoing revascularization, stratified by presence and extent of ischemia (A) and presence or absence of ischemia and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) (B).therapy remains the mainstay treatment for LV dysfunction in either ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathies(5,27), there are significant differences in interventional therapies, including options for revascularization. There is also emerging evidence to remain normal in the presence of multivessel disease and "balanced ischemia"(33). For stress echocardiography, relatively few studies have examined its performance in patients with reduced LVEF. The largest series, including 70 patients, reported sensitivity and specificity of 83% and 71%, respectively(34). Because of its excellent spatial resolution, LGE imaging by CMR has the ability to accurate characterize the location and extent of myocardial scar.Previous studies examining patients with known obstructive CAD and reduced LVEF have detected ischemic pattern LGE in 80% to 100% of cases(35)(36)(37). Diagnostic accuracy of CMR to discern ischemic etiology in patients with new-onset heart failure was >95%, similar to coronary angiography(38). This is of particular significance, given the proportion of patients with prior infarct, but no clinical history of MI, and the prognostic importance of unrecognized MI(39). In our study, ischemicpattern LGE was present in 48% of the cohort but a history of MI in only 24%.A few studies using different imaging modalities have examined the prognostic value of noninvasive stress testing in patients with low LVEF. Majmudar et al. (40) studied 510 consecutive patients referred for stress positron emission tomography with resting LVEF #45%. The presence of scar, but not ischemia, was a univariate predictor of major adverseFIGURE 5 Costs of Downstream Ischemia Testing at 4 Years Costs of cardiac tests to detect myocardial ischemia incurred during follow-up, stratified by stress cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) findings with breakdown by modality. Costs are displayed in U.S. dollars spent per patient. CCTA ¼ coronary computed tomographic angiography; SPECT ¼ singlephoton emission computed tomography.

TABREF59.text: cardiovascular events. In a multivariate model including etiology of LV dysfunction, neither ischemia nor scar was a significant predictor of cardiovascular events. In a substudy of the STITCH trial, which enrolled patients with ischemic heart failure with LVEF #35% and randomized them to CABG in addition to medical therapy, Panza et al.(41) evaluated 399 patients who underwent stress testing. Approximately one-half underwent single-photon emission computed tomography and the other onehalf dobutamine stress echocardiography. Sixty-four percent had evidence of ischemia, and at median follow-up of 56 months, the presence of ischemia did not predict all-cause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, or all-cause mortality plus cardiovascular hospitalization. Our results suggest that stress CMR provides incremental value above a clinical model in predicting long-term hard cardiovascular outcomes and that this finding was independent of LVEF. A few key differences, however, exist between the present study and that reported by Panza et al., including differences in noninvasive modalities, population (suspected or known CAD vs. known CAD), LVEF (median 39% vs. mean 26%), and LV volumes.We reported on the downstream use of invasive angiography, revascularization, and cost of ischemic testing. Consistent with current guidelines (5) and clinical practice, the presence and extent of ischemia were strong drivers behind invasive investigation and revascularization therapy. Referral to angiography remained at the discretion of the treating physician. We observed that 35% of patients with mild, 59% with moderate, and 67% with severe ischemia on stress CMR were referred to angiography. Many studies that have shown benefit of revascularization in ischemic cardiomyopathy(42) were published toward the end of the eligibilityperiod of SPINS (2008 to 2013), which may explain the relatively lower rate of invasive therapy in those with higher burden of ischemia. Fifteen percent of patients with no evidence of ischemia still underwent diagnostic coronary angiography at 90 days, which likely reflects clinical practice at the time of study performance and the clinical recognition of high-risk features. In patients without CMR-detected ischemia who underwent revascularization, the majority had prior infarct. Because this study was conducted before the widespread adoption of fractional flow reserve to guide revascularization, we do not know whether all these interventions would have been performed under current indications. In terms of the cost of care of downstream ischemic testing, presence of ischemia was significant driver of resource use, particularly in the first 90 days, when it was associated with a 3-fold higher cost. The difference in cost was no longer significant after the second year of follow-up. STUDY LIMITATIONS. First, our participating sites consisted of experienced, high-volume CMR centers, and therefore it is unclear whether the results can generalize to less experienced centers. Second, given the retrospective design and limited number of patients who underwent revascularization, we were unable to assess for CMR guidance of medical therapy or coronary revascularization toward improvement of cardiovascular outcomes.Third, there was a limited number of patients with severe LV dysfunction (LVEF <30%), and hence our results may not be generalizable to this population or to those with end-stage ventricular remodeling. Fourth, LVEF determination was by CMR only, so the prognostic value of ischemia and LGE, adjusted to LVEF, may be different than if non-CMR-based LVEF was used. Finally, we excluded patients with a history of CABG from our study; this will have to be addressed in a future study. In this study of patients with impaired LVEF referred for clinical assessment for CAD, presence of ischemia and LGE on stress CMR was associated with worsened long-term cardiovascular prognosis. TABREF62.text: The Stress CMR Top SPINS On and On* Gonzalo Pizarro, MD, PHD T hirty years ago, Atkinson et al. (1) injected a bolus of gadolinium contrast endovenously and observed its transit through the cardiac chambers and myocardium. It was the beginning of cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) perfusion imaging. At that time, dipyridamole vasodilator stress testing was commonly used in thallium-201 perfusion single-photon emission computed tomography scanning. Aiming to demonstrate the superiority of CMR in detecting perfusion abnormalities, Pennell et al. (2) began to perform vasodilator stress protocols inside the magnet. In this scenario, gadolinium injection had 2 different purposes: detection of inducible ischemia on first-pass perfusion imaging and detection of myocardial infarction (MI) on late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) imaging. The technique experienced tremendous technical and clinical development, thereafter, becoming one of the most accurate noninvasive methods for the diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD). During the past decade, numerous studies have been published addressing the prognostic significance of CMR in patients with known or suspected CAD (3). They have been focused mainly on 3 aspects: wall motion abnormalities and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) on cine imaging, presence or extent of infarcted tissue on LGE imaging, and presence or extent of ischemic tissue on stress imaging. To evaluate the capability of stress CMR to stratify the risk of patients with suspected CAD, experienced centers in the United States was published (7). After following up more than 9,000 patients for up to 10 years, the investigators concluded that stress CMR was strongly associated with all-cause mortality. A subgroup of patients with LVEF lower than 55% was analyzed, revealing the same association. The Society for Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance designed and promoted the retrospective SPINS (Stress CMR Perfusion Imaging in the United States) registry, collecting data from 13 CMR centers of excellence (8). A total of 2,349 patients referred for stress CMR were followed for a median period of 5.4 years. The investigators showed that patients without ischemia or scar experienced a very low incidence of cardiovascular events and had low average annual cost for subsequent ischemia testing. The presence of systolic dysfunction in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy is known to confer a higher risk for cardiovascular events. Heart failure (HF) is a complex and not completely understood multiorgan clinical syndrome, in which more than 50% of patients present with CAD as the underlying cause (9). Even though low LVEF is only an occasional component of HF pathophysiology, current guidelines maintain LVEF cutoffs for risk stratification and management. In this issue of iJACC, Ge et al. (10) report an important population: a total of 582 patients with LVEF <50% undergoing clinical vasodilator stress CMR for suspected ischemia (10). The study exploited 2 different sources of data: the aforementioned multicenter SPINS registry and a registry from theBrigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Median LVEF was 39%, with more than one-half of patients ISSN 1936-878X/$36.00 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcmg.2020.06.021 *Editorials published in JACC: Cardiovascular Imaging reflect the views of the authors and do not necessarily represent the views of iJACC or the American College of Cardiology. TABREF63.text: Only 40% of the cohort had a history of HF, and 24% had a history of MI. Abnormal stress CMR results were detected in a total of 321 patients (55%), with either ischemia (30%) or prior MI (48%). The presence of silent ischemia and/or silent MI in patients without a history of CAD is a relevant finding that confirms previous CMR studies (3). The purpose of the study was to demonstrate the capability of stress CMR to stratify the risk of patients with left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction. The primary endpoint was defined as cardiovascular death or nonfatal MI, while the secondary endpoint was defined by a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal MI, hospitalization for unstable angina, hospitalization for congestive HF, and unplanned late CABG.The main results resembled those of the original SPINS study(9), making it possible to reach similar conclusions: after a median follow-up period of 5 years, patients with myocardial ischemia, LGE, or both had higher rates of cardiovascular death and MI.Taking into account that the presence of LV systolic dysfunction is supposed to entail very high risk, it is remarkable to note that the annual primary event rate in patients with neither ischemia nor LGE was as low as 1.1%. When only ischemia or LGE was present, the annual rate was about 3% to 4%, while when both occurred in the same patient, the annual rate was8.8% for the primary endpoint and 17.3% for the secondary endpoint. Importantly, the incremental prognostic value of stress CMR was independent of LVEF. Probably the most important limitation of the study comes from its observational retrospective nature and the potential patient or referral selection bias. Nevertheless, real-world data from registries are necessary to define the potential applications of diagnostic and therapeutic measures. Images were interpreted by local readers with no core laboratory, but the investigators performed a careful quality assurance protocol in an attempt to homogenize the analysis. Quantification of ischemia or LGE (in grams of myocardium or transmurality) can improve the prognostic capacity of stress CMR (11). Ge et al. (10) did not include this information in their prognostic model. Strictly visual interpretation of the images was used to identify the presence or absence of ischemia and LGE, on a per segment and per patient basis. The investigators reached relevant conclusions by interpreting the results in a dichotomic fashion, raising the question of the importance of quantification in clinical stress CMR. Routine qualitative interpretation of ischemic defects and LGE seems to work well for risk stratification in patients with LV systolic dysfunction. Interestingly, the investigators specifically studied ischemic segments location and peri-infarct ischemia, finding that once adjusted for the presence of ischemia or LGE, peri-infarct ischemia was not independently associated with events. Apart from showing the excellent predictive value of stress CMR findings, the authors studied downstream health care costs in the follow-up period, finding, as expected, that the presence of ischemia resulted in higher use of invasive procedures and higher costs during the first 90 days.

TABREF66.text: CMR Assessment of Aldosterone-Induced Cardiac Fibrosis analyses. We compared the baseline characteristics between groups using 1-way analysis of variance(normally distributed variables) or Kruskal-Wallis test (non-normally distributed variable) for continuous variables and with the chi-square test and Fisher exact test for categorical variables. Data were also analyzed by analysis of covariance adjusted on mean BP values measured at the clinical examination. All p values <0.05 were considered as significant. Paired comparisons were made with the Tukey correction for multiple testing on continuous variables. For multiple testing on categorical variables, the paired comparisons were made with Bonferroni correction considering p < 0.0083 as significant. The correlation between variables was tested using the least squares method or the Spearman rank order test. We performed multivariate analysis using sex, age, mean BP, and log-transformed plasma aldosterone concentration as independent variables and LVM index, ECM index, ICM index, and ECM index/ ICM index ratio as dependent variables. Data were reported as percentages for categorical variables, and as mean AE SD for normally distributed continuous variables and median and interquartile range for non-normally distributed continuous variables. SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute, Cary, North Carolina) was used for the analyses. We deemed a p value <0.05 as significant. RESULTS PARTICIPANT CHARACTERISTICS. Age and sex were comparable across the 4 groups (Table 1). As expected, systolic and diastolic BPs were higher in both the HTN and PA groups compared with the HS and BG groups. PA subjects had significantly higher BP levels than HTN subjects did. The total number of antihypertensive drugs prescribed was similar between the PA and HTN groups (p ¼ 0.72). The decreasing rank order of plasma aldosterone concentrations was PA, BG, HTN, and HS. PA and BG patients had an opposite plasma renin profile. CARDIAC MORPHOLOGY AND FUNCTION.Table 2summarizes LV, right ventricular, and left atrial measurements. As expected, LVM index was much higher in both hypertensive groups (PA and HTN) than in both normotensive groups (BG and HS). The decreasing rank order of LVMi was PA, HTN, HS, and BG.

TABREF114.text: ABSTRACT Despite substantial medical advances over the past decades, sudden cardiac death (SCD) remains a leading cause of cardiovascular deaths in patients with ischemic heart disease. The presence of structural heart disease with left ventricular ejection fraction <35% is the current criteria for implantable cardioverter-defibrillator therapy as a primary prevention to SCD. However, more than 80% of patients who suffer SCD have a left ventricular ejection fraction >35%, whereas few patients who received an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator required appropriate defibrillation. Cardiac magnetic
