TABREF121.text: Selected Ongoing Trials and Observational Studies Using Cardiac Magnetic Resonance for Risk Stratification in Ischemic Heart DiseaseNCT01197677Patients undergoing CMR (enrolled into the "European clinical practice"-part of the registry Consecutive patients with suspected coronary artery disease or with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (enrolled into the specific protocols "suspected CAD" or "HCM-SCD")DCM ¼ nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy; ECV ¼ extracellular volume fraction; HCM ¼ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; HF ¼ heart failure; IHM ¼ ischemic heart disease; LVAD ¼ left ventricular assist device; MACE ¼ major adverse cardiovascular event(s); RV ¼ right ventricular; other abbreviations as in Tables 2 and 3. semiquantitative LGE quantification method is the full width at half maximum technique, which takes half of the maximal signal intensity within the scar as a cutoff for a scarred myocardium and seems to be the most reproducible technique (41). Using different LGE quantification methods results in different LGE sizes (43), with significant implications for risk stratification. These differences in LGE extent are explained by the limited spatial resolution of CMR rendering partial volume effects unavoidable (44). As a consequence, the LGE signal becomes patchy, and large gray zones are present. Nevertheless, this heterogeneity is not only due to technical limitations but also has a pathophysiological basis that holds substantial clinical relevance.

TABREF122.text: ). Strengthening the value of the LGE gray zone even further, these studies have found a doseresponse effect-patients with a larger extent of LGE gray zone have a higher arrhythmic risk(36). In an animal study investigating imaging findings of the peri-infarct zone in pigs comparing histology, the authors found that an infarct scar and a viable myocardium were clearly delineated in all chronic myocardial infarctions, and islands of viable myocytes could be detected by Masson trichrome staining at the border zone of the infarcts(48). Therefore, it can be suggested that the bundles of the viable myocardium mix with the fibrotic scar tissue in the gray zone, indicating that re-entry routes for the slow electrical conduction might exist in the inhomogeneous infarct tissue. Furthermore, in a high magnetic field (7.0-T CMR scan) validation study, Schelbert et al.(49) found that by analyzing the histology andLGE of pigs' hearts after myocardial infarction, the border between the viable myocardium and theinfarct on histological sections revealed that some borders had sharp and distinct transitions between fibrotic regions and viable cardiomyocytes, but others demonstrated mixtures of viable myocytes and patches or fingers of fibrosis. Histological and highresolution LGE images identify both the heterogeneous peri-infarct border zone, where mixtures of viable cardiomyocytes and collections of fibrosis are intermingled, as well as the distinct edge of the infarct, where the infarct and myocardium are separate. However, after retrospective degradation of CMR images to a lower resolution (i.e., comparable with the resolution of clinical scans), the apparent size of the intermediate signal intensity peri-infarct border zone increased significantly as a function of resolution. This partial volume error only affected the sharp and distinct borders of the infarct, and the proportion of infarcted myocardium did not change significantly as image resolution was degraded (49). Therefore, image resolution has to be taken into account when assessing LGE gray zones. LGE gray zone needs to be optimized and standardized to allow clinical implementation because the current protocols involve complex and operator-dependent procedures. T1 MAPPING, ECV, AND T2 MAPPING. Although LGE is a sensitive method in detecting myocardial replacement fibrosis, it has limited capacity in discriminating interstitial fibrosis from a normal myocardium. Interstitial fibrosis is usually diffuse and microscopic; thus, it does not result in visual focal changes of signal intensity. Diffuse interstitial fibrosis can be assessed by native T1 mapping of the myocardium. Native T1 mapping allows quantification based on pixel values of T1 in each voxel and can depict even relatively small variations of T1 within the extracellular and intracellular compartments.Native T1 can change with a number of processes such as lipid accumulation, edema, and interstitial fibrosis, and, therefore, this technique has the potential to more accurately detect fibrosis (compared with signal intensity in arbitrary units)(50). With the use of extracellular paramagnetic contrast agents, structural changes in the myocardium can be "amplified." Therefore, by mapping T1 before and after gadolinium, the ECV of the myocardium can be quantitatively calculated and serves as a surrogate for diffuse fibrosis. Several studies have confirmed a close correlation of myocardial ECV with histopathologically determined collagen volume fraction assessed from endomyocardial biopsies from patients(51,52);

TABREF123.text: Therefore, more evidence is needed in order to evaluate the value to guide therapy and potentially improve patient selection for ICD implantation using these new mapping techniques. T2 mapping, an emerging valuable clinical tool for better noninvasive assessment of myocardial edema than traditional T2weighted imaging, was shown in patients with acute myocardial infarction to accurately distinguish an infarcted from a salvaged myocardium(57). Whether and to what degree T2 mapping has significance in the risk stratification of sudden cardiac death remains unknown. FEATURE TRACKING. Left ventricular strain defined as the deformation of the myocardium can be assessed in echocardiography and CMR feature tracking. In a recent study, CMR feature trackingbased global longitudinal strain was independently associated with all-cause death in IHD. In fact, each 1% worsening in global longitudinal strain was associated with an 89.1% increased risk of death after adjustment for clinical and imaging risk factors including LVEF and LGE. The risk stratification could be refined by adding global longitudinal strain to the model, which resulted in a significant tion does not directly represent arrhythmogenic substrate but may rather act as a surrogate marker, this technique might be particularly useful when dealing with patients with contraindications for gadolinium-based contrast agents, when CMR scan time is an issue, and/or when LGE images are of nondiagnostic quality.THERAPIES AND FUTURE PERSPECTIVESCurrent guideline-recommended therapies for the treatment or prevention of SCD in IHD consist of optimal reperfusion strategies, treatment of predisposing risk factors, medications, catheter ablation of arrhythmia, and ICD implantation.MEDICATION. Besides antiarrhythmic medication (see later) and pharmacological prevention of ischemia using statins and platelet aggregation inhibitors, rapid reperfusion therapy (i.e., percutaneous coronary intervention and coronary artery bypass grafting) results in a decrease of SCD risk in patients presenting with an acute coronary syndrome. Moreover, observational data in chronic coronary artery disease have shown that coronary reperfusion strategies added to optimal medical therapy modify the risk for SCD when noninvasively assessed ischemia exceeds 10% of the left myocardium (59). Medications are essential to controlling arrhythmia and improving symptoms in IHD across all LVEF subgroups. Among IHD patients with preserved LVEF, at present only the use of beta-blockers has demonstrated survival benefits toward SCD in randomized controlled trials. However, in patients with left ventricular dysfunction, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (either an angiotensin-converting enzyme [ACE] inhibitor or an angiotensin receptor blocker [ARB]), an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, and antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., beta-blocker, amiodarone, and sotalol) have been shown to reduce the risk for SCD (60-62). With the advance of guidelinedirected medical therapies (GDMTs), patient mortality had declined among those with left ventricular dysfunction due to either ischemic or nonischemic causes (63). GDMTs may improve clinical outcomes and reduce the need for ICD therapy among patients whose heart failure demonstrates a response to medical therapy (64,65). Therefore, clinical trials are needed to evaluate the incremental benefits of ICD over GDMT in the modern era. Although beta-blockers reduce the arrhythmogenic effects of sympathetic stimulation, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and aldosterone receptor antagonists have been demonstrated to reverse remodeling and consecutively decrease fibrosis, a substrate and trigger for ventricular arrhythmia as outlined previously (66). This finding is of particular interest because these indirect-acting "antifibrotic" medications are readily available in clinical routine. One may speculate that patients with increased levels of diffuse fibrosis may benefit from more intense treatment by ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and aldosterone receptor antagonists. Future studies have to investigate whether CMR can optimize treatment strategy in these patients. The significance of fibrosis is not only emerging to predict SCD but also in heart failure overall (67). The consequences of myocardial interstitial fibrosis are detrimental to the failing heart, and a specific antifibrotic treatment would be appealing. However, the knowledge on the cellular and molecular mechanisms of fibrosis have poorly translated into diagnostics and therapeutics. This has partly been due to the paucity of instruments to identify myocardial fibrosis. Yet, the potential of stem cells and cardiac regenerative therapies targeting fibroblast regulation needs to be elucidated to identify possible therapeutic approaches to limit progressive cardiac fibrosis as the underlying arrhythmogenic substrate (68). ABLATION. If medication is not effective, not tolerated, or not desired by the patient, catheter ablation is an option in patients with symptomatic sustained VT. A recent trial showed that radiofrequency ablation of VT reduced the combined endpoint of mortality, VT storms, and appropriate shocks over drug/ antiarrhythmic treatment (69). Furthermore, radiofrequency catheter ablation reduced implantable ICD shocks and VT episodes in patients with sustained VT with IHD at follow-up (69-72). However, its impact on long-term patient mortality remains unknown at present. Moreover, to date, no trial has specifically assessed radiofrequency ablation versus standard medical therapy in patients with VT toward SCD as the primary outcome measure. Considering that the LGE gray zone has been described as the strongest predictor of appropriate ICD therapy (even outperforming LGE extent) (45), CMR-guided ablation could improve ablation success or potentially even defer ICD implantation. ICD IMPLANTATION. Although the cost-effectiveness ratio is below the $100,000 per quality-adjusted lifeyear threshold (73), prophylactic ICD implantation is associated with enormous health care expenditures given the combined cost of implanting ICD (i.e., Medicare reimburses about $30,000 per case), monitoring, and the downstream generator exchange.There is a large number of potentially eligible patients (i.e., more than 500,000 Medicare beneficiaries)(74).Current Class I recommendations for ICD implantation do not effectively use the therapeutic benefits of ICD therapy(1,2). SCD presents as a first cardiac event in approximately 50% of all patients who suffered an SCD(2). The majority of patients who presented with SCD have LVEF >35%(75,76). Conversely, over 80% of patients who underwent implantation of an ICD per current guideline recommendations never received an appropriate shock during follow-up of over 8 years(77), and approximately 10% of ICD patients experience inappropriate shocks (78) that are associated with both increased morbidity and mortality and substantial health care use and expenditures(79). As a result, current recommendations for ICD therapy suffer from inadequate risk stratification.Another issue is the low adherence to guidelines in patients eligible for ICD implantation. Approximately one-quarter of patients who receive an ICD to prevent SCD do not meet evidence-based indications for implantation(80), and <10% of eligible patients had an ICD implanted within 1 year after myocardial infarction(81). In the secondary prevention of SCD, an ICD is recommended after ischemia warranting revascularization has been excluded, and the patient is expected to live longer than 1 year. Conversely, the recommendations are more complex in the primary prevention of SCD. In patients with IHD, an ICD is indicated if LVEF is below 35% in patients with New York Heart Association functional class II or III, below 30% in patients with New York Heart Association functional class I, or below 40% if sustained VT is induced during electrophysiological study(1).HOW IMAGING MAY AID IN THERAPEUTIC DECISIONS.To date, none of the imaging modalities have been evaluated in a prospective randomized controlled trial setting guiding ICD therapy toward the improvement of outcomes. Challenges in conducting such randomized controlled trials include the established practice pattern of ICD implantation using current LVEF cutoff criteria, the high costs of ICD and subsequent monitoring, and the low relative risks of SCD in the large number of IHD patients at risk with only mild to moderate left ventricular dysfunction.

TABREF124.text: arrhythmic environment, myocardial fibrosis is considered an arrhythmogenic substrate. CMR has emerged as the modality of choice to display scarring and diffuse fibrosis. Because these parameters are strong predictors of SCD, CMR is considered a promising tool to improve risk stratification in patients with IHD with preserved and reduced LVEF. TABREF125.text: A 78-year-old woman underwent mitral valve replacement (27-mm Medtronic Mosaic) to treat mitral regurgitation. She was part of a control group of patients prospectively evaluated by seriated 18 F-FDG PET/CTA after valve replacement surgery. Fused PET/CTA image at the mitral plane. The prosthesis shows very low FDG uptake at 1 month after implantation surgery and then very intense metabolic activity at 6 and 12 months. Although the SUVmax values overlap with those observed in infection, the prosthesis displays a diffuse and homogeneous distribution pattern characteristic of post-operative reactive inflammation. In addition, no IE-related anatomical lesions appeared during follow-up. In this sense, it is very important to have keep in mind that, among other surgical information, knowing the type of prosthesis can be relevant when interpreting a PET/CTA study for the diagnosis of endocarditis, regarding that not every FDG uptake implies infection.

TABREF128.text: CMR of Pediatric Cardiac Tumors Impact of Left Atrial Phasic Function in Heart Failure With Preserved Ejection Fraction Insights From Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Feature Tracking fibrillation at the time of CMR were excluded. The primary endpoint was HF hospitalization and/or cardiovascular death. Dedicated software (Circle Cardiovascular Imaging, Calgary, Alberta, Canada) was used for feature tracking analysis of the LA wall. The ethics committee of the Medical University of Vienna approved the study protocol (EK 796/2010). Univariate and multivariate Cox regression analyses were used to determine the prognostic relevance of phasic LA size and functional parameters. In addition, the Spearman (r) test was used to define factors correlated with LA phasic function. Baseline LA volumetric results included a maximum volume index (VI) of 55 AE 19 ml/m 2 , LAVI prior to LA contraction of 44 AE 16 ml/m 2 , minimum LAVI of 35 AE 17 ml/m 2 , and total LAEF of 39 AE 11%. The reservoir strain rate was 102%/s (IQR: 80 to 136); the conduit strain rate was À77 %/s (IQR: 60 to 114); and the booster pump strain rate was À105%/s tions [17%], and 6 deaths [6%]). All parameters, except for maximum LAVI, were related with outcome by univariate Cox regression analysis. Two clustered multivariate regression models were applied. The volumetric parameters LAVI prior to atrial contraction, minimal LAVI, and total LAEF were included in model 1. Model 2 consisted of LA conduit strain rate, booster pump strain rate, and reservoir strain rate. Echocardiographic studies have shown that LA function in HFpEF is strongly associated with cardiovascular outcome and pulmonary vascular disease(1). In comparison with echocardiography, CMR provides superior spatial resolution, which allows exact cardiac wall motion measurements and atrial strain and strain rate analyses (2-4) but at the cost of temporal resolution and real-time imaging. The present results indicate that LA conduit function represents an important pathomechanistic determinant in HFpEF. It is closely linked to pulmonary vascular function and exercise capacity and ultimately cardiovascular outcome. These findings complement those from prior studies also showing that LA conduit function is closely and independently particularly CMR-derived LAEF and LA conduit strain rate can detect mechanical changes at earlier stages and are therefore superior to static LA volumetric measures in predicting adverse events in HFpEF (3). However, the use of CMR feature tracking for the assessment of LA conduit function is limited in clinical routine. Moreover, reference values for myocardial feature tracking are not established, and significant intervendor variability has been described (5). Therefore, LAEF could be used in daily practice. The present and other data support its superiority as a risk predictor over still widely used maximal LA expansion (1). Progressive aortic valve calcification (AVC) plays a central role in aortic stenosis (AS). Until recently, quantitative assessment of AVC distribution was not measurable in vivo. Computed tomography (CT) now provides high-quality, simple, and reproducible AVC quantification. We developed en face aortic valve imaging by re-registering CT datasets to precisely map and quantify AVC, aiming to analyze AVC distribution between and within cusps and to link those to AS severity. We included 418 subjects (age 76 AE 9 years, 69% men; ejection fraction >50%: 84%; n ¼ 200 from the Mayo Clinic [Rochester, Minnesota], n ¼ 218 from the

TABREF129.text: AVCd 450 [interquartile range (IQR): 250 to 666] AU/cm 2 ), and severe calcification was common (49% with severe AVCd [men $476 AU/cm 2 , women $292 AU/cm 2 ]). Noncontrast CT datasets were reorientated en face using 3-dimensional multiplanar reconstruction. Each cusp was identified through its relationship to the sinuses of Valsalva and the interatrial septum. volume-rendered datasets were used to confirm anatomy and illustrate relationships between calcification distribution and systolic cusp movement. En face AVC mapping was performed cusp by cusp (quantified as the percentage of total calcium in the same view and expressed as absolute AVCd per cusp) and by assessing cusp-edge calcium extension, in which each cusp free-edge commissural segment was counted as calcium positive (score 1) if $50% was occupied by calcium, summating the valve ranging from 0 to 6 (Figure 1). Total valve edge calcification was categorized as none or mild (score 0 to 2), moderate (score 3 to 5), or severe (score 6). In 20 patients (55% severe AVCd) intra-and interobserver reproducibility of these measures were assessed, Our first result confirms that AVC is not evenly distributed. AVC mapping demonstrated consistent differences between cusps, with a most to least calcified cusp AVCd difference of 112 (IQR: 66 to 182) AU/cm 2 . Second, this AVC inhomogeneity is not random; in 61% of patients, AVC predominated in the noncoronary cusp, whether AS was hemodynamically severe or not (63% vs. 61%; p ¼ 0.65), and accounted for 43 AE 17% of total AVC. Calcification of the right and left coronary cusp approximated each other (27 AE 13% vs. 29 AE 14% of total AVC; p ¼ 0.42), and the specific cusp affected as most or least calcified showed no associations with AS severity. Third, relationships between AVC distribution and hemodynamic severity emerge: although AVCd differences between the most and least calcified cusps were larger in patients with hemodynamically severe versus moderate AS (145 [IQR: 103 to 215] AU/cm 2 vs. 80 [IQR: 46 to 119] AU/cm 2 ; p < 0.001), the presence of significant AVC asymmetry (defined as 1 cusp with <20% of total AVC) was univariately associated with nonsevere AS (p < 0.001).Fourth, the distribution of calcification within cusps is heterogenous. AVC was limited to commissures in 9% of cusps, extending with or without annular extension into incomplete or complete arcs (41% and 35% of cusps, respectively) (p < 0.001).Cusp-edge calcification not only increases in extent with severe calcification, but also varies considerably for any given AVC burden (Figure 1); this heterogeneity in AVC location has important hemodynamic consequences. TABREF130.text: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcmg.2020.04.024 © 2020 by the American College of Cardiology Foundation. Published by Elsevier.Please note: Dr. Clavel has received research grant support from Medtronic; and has served as a consultant for Edwards Lifesciences. Dr. Messika-Zeitoun has served as a consultant for Edwards Lifesciences. All other authors have reported that they have no relationships relevant to the contents of this paper to disclose. The authors attest they are in compliance with human studies committees and animal welfare regulations of the authors' institutions and Food and Drug Administration guidelines, including patient consent where appropriate. For more information, visit the JACC: Cardiovascular Imaging author instructions page.Cardiomyopathy, characterized by non-ischemic myocardial fibrosis of the left ventricle (LV) with a myocarditis-like pattern, is a frequent cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD)-as it leads to systolic dysfunction, heart failure (HF) and arrhythmias (1). Tissue characterization by late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) is a valuable tool for early detection and monitoring progression of myocardial fibrosis in the dystrophic heart (2). We previously showed that LV ejection fraction (LV-EF) #45% and a "transmural" pattern of LGE independently predict cardiac events in DMD/BMD (3). We aimed to describe the progression of cardiomyopathy by serial CMR and to relate it to the development of cardiovascular events. We prospectively enrolled 91 MD males (median age 29, interquartile range [IQR]: 21 to 43 years; 19 DMD/72 BMD) in whom at least 2 CMRs were performed-1 baseline and at least 1 follow-up. The study protocol complies with the Declaration of Helsinki and was approved by the local ethics committees. Informed consent was obtained from the patients prior to study inclusion. In addition to standard volumetric analysis of cine images, LGEwhen present-was quantified ($3 SD above normal myocardium) and expressed as % of LV mass. A transmural pattern was considered whenever $1 segment presented transmural LGE. The patients were followed up for a composite endpoint comprising cardiac death/transplantation (HTx) or either of: HF hospitalization, non-/sustained ventricular tachycardia (nsVT/VT). An arrhythmic endpoint was defined as detection of nsVT/VT in the surviving patients. At baseline, 92% of patients reported NYHA functional class I/II HF. Patients with DMD were significantly younger than BMD (14, IQR: 12 to 22 vs. 36, IQR: 24 to 46 years; p < 0.001). At baseline CMR, 43% of patients had a LV-EF <55% and 68% showed (exclusively non-ischemic) LGE. Twenty-five percent of patients had a LV-EF #45%, while LV-EF#35% was seen in 7%. Among LGE-positive patients, 24% presented a transmural LGE-pattern. LGE extent ranged from 1% to 44% with median of 9%. A high negative correlation between LGE extent and LV-EF was noted (Spearman-Rho -0.72; p < 0.001). positive (80% vs. 68%; p ¼ 0.001) and had higher percentage of transmural LGE (37% vs. 24%; p < 0.0001) vs. baseline. In the LGE-positive patients at baseline (n ¼ 62), LV-EF decreased from 50 AE 10% to 48 AE 10% (p < 0.001) on average with 0.7%/year and LGE extent increased from median 9% (IQR: 4% to 23%) to 12% (IQR: 7% to 27%) (p < 0.001) on average with 0.7%/year. The prevalence of transmural LGE almost doubled in these patients (from 24% to 44%; p < 0.001). In N ¼ 11 initially LGE-free patients becoming LGE-positive at follow-up, median LGE extent was 2% (IQR: 1 to 9), none of them showing a transmural pattern. Among them, only a mildly impaired LV-EF was present in 4 at follow-up. During total follow-up of median 6 years (1 to 11 years), 4 cardiac deaths and 1 HTx occurred. Thirty-five further endpoints occurred in another 30 patients (three experienced 2 and 1 three nonfatal, non-HTx endpoints): HF hospitalizations in N ¼ 8, sustained VT in n ¼ 4 and nonsustained VT episodes in n ¼ 23 patients. Thus, the composite endpoint occurred in 38% (n ¼ 35) of patients. The secondary arrhythmic endpoint (nsVT/VT) occurred in 30% (n ¼ 27) of DMD/BMD. nsVTs were exclusively detected on repeated ambulatory monitoring using an external event loop recorder and were mostly asymptomatic. Patients with a composite endpoint showed significantly lower EF and higher LGE prevalence, extent and frequency of transmural pattern at baseline and follow-up (Table 1). There was a significant difference in LV-EF worsening to #45% in MD with vs. without events (17% vs. 2%; p ¼ 0.012). In a multivariable model including 3 CMR parameters, all of them were independent predictors for the composite endpoint: (1) LV-EF #45% at baseline (OR: 8.5; 95% CI 2.3 to 30.9; p ¼ 0.001); (2) transmural LGE at baseline (OR: 14.6; 95% CI 1.6 to 136.4; p ¼ 0.019) and (3) development of LV-EF #45% at follow-up (odds ratio [OR]: 21.6; 95% CI 2.2 to 211.2; p ¼ 0.008). In a second multivariable model including the same parameters, all 3 were independent predictors for the arrhythmic endpoint: (1) LV-EF #45%

BMD ¼ Becker muscular dystrophy; CMR ¼ cardiac magnetic resonance; DMD ¼ Duchenne muscular dystrophy; LGE ¼ late gadolinium enhancement; LV ¼ left ventricle; LV-EDV ¼ left ventricular end-diastolic volume; LV-EF ¼ left ventricular ejection fraction; LV-ESV ¼ left ventricular end-systolic volume; NA ¼ not applicable. Does a Prior Normal Transthoracic Echocardiogram Negate the Need for Another Echocardiogram? Noninvasive transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is commonly performed in the evaluation of syncope.However, despite its utility as a diagnostic tool, TTE for syncope is associated with higher costs and length of stay, without a mortality impact (1). Therefore, risk stratification of syncope patients prior to TTE referral could reduce health care costs. As the overall rate of TTE use rises nationally(2), many syncope patients are likely to have had a prior TTE. To our knowledge, no study has assessed whether data from a prior TTE can help predict the diagnostic yield of a new TTE in patients presenting with syncope. We hypothesized that information from a prior TTE would allow providers to better riskstratify patients, and thereby both improve diagnostic yield for those with a prior abnormal TTE and reduce the need for another TTE for those with a prior normal TTE. We retrospectively identified 2,000 consecutive TTEs performed for syncope between November 11, 2013, and November 26, 2017, at a large academic medical center. A total of 27 TTEs were excluded for erroneous coding, and 3 were uninterpretable due to very poor image quality. The remaining 1,970 TTEs (mean age 63 years; 52% women) included 31.2% (n ¼ 615) with a prior TTE in our electronic database, dating back to July 1, 2000 (time since prior TTE <1 year for 32.0%, >5 years for 28.8%). Older age, African-American race, and inpatient status were associated with a higher likelihood of having a prior TTE (71.1 years vs. 59.7 years, 19.1% vs. 12.9%, and 68.8% vs. 62.9%, respectively, all p #0.01). TTE reports were independently reviewed for any findings to potentially explain syncope using the criteria in

TABREF132.text: infarction, which are diagnosed by other more definitive tests, findings on TTE to potentially explain syncope usually have an insidious onset. However, our findings contradict this hypothesis, and suggest that the presentation of syncope correlates with the development of TTE findings despite a normal prior TTE. In conclusion, our retrospective cohort study of 1,970 consecutive TTEs performed for the evaluation of syncope demonstrates that a prior normal TTE does not affect the TTE-positive diagnostic yield. Therefore, patients presenting with syncope should be considered for TTE despite the presence of a prior normal TTE. Further research should assess how specific findings on a prior TTE correlate with outcomes in patients presenting with syncope, and include this type of information in risk stratification models.

TABREF134.text: 3). We aimed to evaluate whether LA impairment may precede LV remodeling, representing an expression of atrial myopathy related to Gb3 accumulation. In this retrospective, observational study, 45 patients with AFD underwent CMR with T1 mapping using shortened modified Look-Locker inversion recovery sequences, 2-dimensional echocardiography, and quantification of Mainz Severity Score Index (MSSI). Patients were divided into 3 groups (n ¼ 15 each) with increasing severity: 1) normal T1, no LVH; 2) low T1, no LVH; and 3) LVH. Patients were compared with 15 healthy control subjects. CMR-FT was applied for the analysis of LA strain (total, conduit, booster) and volumes. Mean age of the patients with AFD was 38.5 AE 15.1 years; there were 34 (56%) men. No differences in sex distribution and "classic" mutation prevalence were found between groups. Higher values of global or cardiovascular MSSI, rate of patients assuming enzyme replacement therapy, indexed LV mass, LV maximum wall thickness, and late gadolinium enhancement-positive segments were observed from groups 1 to 3, reflecting a gradient of disease severity. Native T1 values were normal in healthy control subjects and in group 1 patients and were progressively lower in group 2 and 3. LA total strain was comparable between control subjects and patients in group 1 (36.8 AE 6.4% vs. 36.8 AE 6.0%; p ¼ 0.45), while a significant difference was found between group 1 and group 2 (36.8 AE 6.4% vs. 29.9 AE 5.2%; p ¼ 0.01). Group 3 showed a significantly reduced LA total strain compared with all other groups (19.6 AE 4.8%; p < 0.001 for all). A progressive reduction in LA conduit strain was observed from control subjects to group 3, paralleling the increase in patients with echocardiographic diastolic dysfunction. No difference among groups was found in LA booster strain values (Figure 1). Atrial volumes were significantly increased in group 3 compared with the other groups. Overall, LA total strain showed very good correlation with native septal T1, LV maximum wall thickness, atrial volumes, and global or cardiovascular MSSI. Univariate regression analysis showed a significant association between LA total strain and age, native septal T1, and MSSI but not with sex or presence of "classic" mutations. This is the first study systematically assessing LA function by CMR-FT in a population of patients with AFD stratified according to the degree of LV involvement. Atrial deformation was already impaired in patients with AFD with low T1 values (tracking Gb3 deposition), even in the absence of LVH and diastolic dysfunction. This is consistent with the concept of an atrial myopathy directly caused by Gb3 deposition, primarily affecting atrial compliance.

TABREF135.text: Tomography-Derived An Exploratory Analysis on Diagnostic Performance Fractional flow reserve derived from coronary computed tomography angiography (FFR CT ) is an emerging noninvasive modality that accurately identifies ischemic vessels (1), although recent evidence suggests that gray-zone FFR CT values between 0.70 to 0.80 are associated with only modest diagnostic accuracy. The ischemic myocardial burden is an established metric used to guide clinical decision making and is traditionally assessed using noninvasive stress imaging. The potential to incorporate FFR CT values ("depth" of ischemia), together with CT-derived ischemic myocardial burden ("extent" of ischemia), has yet to be explored and may improve the diagnosis of hemodynamically significant coronary stenosis. Therefore, the aim of this study was to evaluate the incremental diagnostic performance of FFR CTcompared with FFR CT alone in FFR CT significant vessels (#0.80). This is a subanalysis of the NXT (Analysis of Coronary Blood Flow Using CT Angiography: Next Steps) trial, a prospective study of stable coronary artery disease patients undergoing CT angiography, FFR CT , and FFR (1). We included 109 patients and 181 vessels with FFR CT #0.80 (mean age 63.0 AE 9.7 years; 75% men). Burden of ischemic myocardium was defined as percentage of left ventricular myocardium subtended beyond the point at which the vessel FFR CT becomes #0.80, as estimated by the APPROACH (APPROACH FFRCT ) score (Figures 1A to 1C). The APPROACH (Alberta Provincial Project for Outcome Assessment in Coronary Heart Disease) score is a cardiac magnetic resonance-validated scoring matrix providing an anatomic estimate of the myocardial territory at risk based on vessel

TABREF136.text: ). The primary endpoint was incremental discrimination of per-vessel FFR #0.80 when combining the APPROACH FFRCT score with FFR CT compared with FFR CT alone as assessed by the area under the receiver-operating characteristic improvement index (IDI) in FFR CT significant vessels (#0.80). The Youden index was used to determine the optimal threshold of the APPROACH FFRCT score to identify FFR #0.80 vessels. The inter-and intraoperator reproducibility of the APPROACH FFRCT score was assessed using the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). The local ethics committees approved the study protocol. FFR was measured in 102 (94%) patients and in 118 (65%) vessels, of which 57% (n ¼ 67 of 118) had an FFR #0.8. Mean time for APPROACH FFRCT assessment was 21.3 AE 9.4 s. The interoperator ICC was 0.99 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.97 to 0.99; p < 0.001) and intraoperator ICC 0.95 (95% CI: 0.88 to 0.98; p < 0.001). The optimal threshold for APPROACH FFRCT was >27.5%. When combining the APPROACH FFRCT score with FFR CT , there was significantly higher discrimination compared with FFR CT alone (AUC: 0.75 [95% CI: 0.65 to 0.84] vs. 0.69 [95% CI: 0.59 to 0.78]; FIGURE 1 APPROACH FFRCT Methodology and Incremental Diagnostic Performance of Combined FFRCT and APPROACH FFRCT Compared With FFR CT Alone Side-branch:Small Vessel:LAD Location:Distal3. Estimate Ischemic Myocardial BurdenUsing APPROACH Score

TABREF137.text: and improve decision making. The APPROACH FFRCT score is only a semiquantitative estimate of ischemic myocardial burden, and more refined techniques now exist that provide vessel-specific fractional myocardial mass (5). Future studies are needed to further investigate the diagnostic and prognostic value of the APPROACH FFRCT technique, including validation of the optimal diagnostic threshold. The integration of such techniques with FFR CT and emerging metrics such as shear stress and high-risk plaque quantification may have the potential to transform cardiac CT into an even more sophisticated platform for predicting cardiovascular risk and guiding therapeutic decision making. Analysis Using Feature-Tracking CMR to Detect LV Systolic Dysfunction in Myocardial Iron Overload Disease Iron-induced cardiomyopathy with progressive heart failure is the leading cause of death in patients with systemic iron overload, and early detection is vital for chelator therapy (1). The transverse relaxation time T2* (¼1/R2*) nonlinearly reflects tissue iron concentration and allows pre-symptomatic detection of myocardial iron deposition using cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR). Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is the reference standard for evaluating systolic function. However, its sensitivity to indicate iron-induced cardiomyopathy is limited to later disease stages. Instead, myocardial strain has been shown to detect cardiac dysfunction even at subclinical levels in various diseases (2). We aimed to investigate the diagnostic performance of feature-tracking CMR to indicate systolic cardiac impairment due to myocardial iron toxicity. This study was approved by the ethics committee of the General Medical Council for Hamburg, Germany. Patients with systemic iron overload disease (n ¼ 123; mean age 29 AE 14 years) and 47 control subjects (mean age 31 AE 12 years) underwent CMR using a 4-element phased-array coil (1.5-T; Symphony, Siemens Healthcare GmbH, Erlangen, Germany). Multi-slice short-axis cine steady-state freeprecision images were acquired (TE ¼ 1.6 ms, TR ¼ 50 ms, FA ¼ 65 , slice thickness ¼ 6 mm, phases ¼ 25). For assessing the transverse myocardial relaxation time T2*, a multipurpose iron measureelectrocardiogram-gated, TR/TE1/DTE ¼ 244/1.3/ 1.16 ms, Nte ¼ 12, FA ¼ 20 , bandwidth ¼ 1,955 Hz/ pixel). A monoexponential function with constant signal offset was applied to region of interest-based signal intensities of the mid-papillary septum. Elevated myocardial iron levels were defined by a conservative threshold of T2* <20 ms. LVEF was analyzed by semi-automated delineation of epicardial and endocardial contours using a dedicated software (cvi42, Circle Cardiovascular Imaging Inc., Calgary, Alberta, Canada); trabeculae and papillary muscles were included in the ventricular volumes and excluded from the myocardial mass for better reproducibility (3). Myocardial strain was determined by using the feature-tracking software Segment version 2.1.R.6108 (Medviso, Lund, Sweden). The entire image content (i.e., blood pool, entire myocardium) is used during the optimization process instead of tracking only the myocardial boundaries (4). Global radial strain (GRS) and global longitudinal strain (GLS) were measured on 3 long-axis cine series and global circumferential strain (GCS) on 3 short-axis cine series (4). In patients with septal T2* <20 ms (group A: 66 of 123) and T2* >20 ms (group B), median T2* with quartiles [25% to 75%] of 9.3 [6.3 to 11.1] ms and 33 [27 to 37] ms were obtained, respectively. Median ferritin levels in group A were higher compared with those in group B (2,208 [1,225 to 5,185] mg/l vs. 1,093 [532 to 1,990] mg/l; p < 0.001) and in the control subjects (group C: 88 [38 to 136] mg/l). pair-wise comparisons among groups A, B, and C, a post hoc test (Games-Howell test) was used: LVEF was decreased in group A compared with group B (54 AE 14% vs. 61 AE 6%; p < 0.01), whereas group B did not differ from group C (62 AE 6%; p ¼ 0.5). All strain parameters (GRS, GCS, and GLS) were significantly decreased in group A compared with group B, especially GLS (-15 AE 3% vs. -18 AE 3%; p < 0.0001). Comparing groups B and C, both GRS and GLS were different (p < 0.0001), although GCS was not (p ¼ 0.6). Receiver-operating characteristic analysis resulted in the highest area under the curve (AUC) of 0.91 (p < 0.0001; 95% CI: 0.85 to 0.96) and a cutoff defined by Youden's index >À19% for GLS to indicate impairment of systolic LV function in group A with a sensitivity of 88% (95% CI: 78 to 95) and a specificity of 79% (95% CI: 64 to 89) (Figure 1A). AUC values for GRS (0.80; 95% CI: 0.72 to 0.87) and GCS (0.77; 95% CI: 0.69 to 0.85) were higher than for LVEF (0.68; 95% CI: 0.58 to 0.76). AUC values in group B

TABREF138.text: Consecutive patients with known or suspected PH referred for CMR examination and who underwent right heart catheterization (RHC) within 3 months were considered for inclusion. Patients <18 years of age, with an absence of PH in the RHC, group 2 PH, and incomplete clinical or CMR data were excluded. Steady-state free precession cine imaging was used to quantify RV volumes, and flow imaging perpendicular to the main pulmonary artery (PA) was used to calculate stroke volume (SV). Coupling was estimated Hybrid method: We combined RHC and CMR information such as Ea ¼ (mean PA pressure À PA wedge pressure)/SV (where SV is obtained from PA flow imaging) and Ees ¼ mean PA pressure/endsystolic volume (ESV). CMR flow method: The numerator for Ea was simplified as mean PA pressure alone, so that Ea/ Ees could be expressed as ESV/SV, with SV again obtained from PA flow imaging. CMR volume method: Coupling is also simplified as ESV/SV, but SV was obtained from cine images. All individuals consented to the procedures, and the Mount Sinai Hospital Institutional Review Board approved the study with a waiver of informed consent. A total of 133 patients were included; their mean age was 53.3 AE 13.5 years, 72.2% were female, 69.2% had pulmonary arterial hypertension, 12% had PH secondary to lung disease, 5.3% had chronic thromboembolic PH, and 13.5% had miscellaneous etiologies. Mean PA pressure was 45.2 AE 11.6 mm Hg, RVEF was 37.1 AE 14.5%, and Ea/Ees (Hybrid method) was 2.3 AE 3.1. During a median follow-up of 3.4 years, 73 (54.9%) patients died. Patients who died were more often male, used diuretic agents more commonly, and had lower RVEF, larger RV volumes, and pericardial effusions. Notably, low PA oxygen saturation was the only invasive index associated with increased mortality. In Cox regression analyses, the Hybrid and Flow methods were independently associated with death after accounting for age, sex, PA oxygen saturation, RVEF, diuretic use, or pericardial effusion (adjusted hazard ratio [aHR]: 1.103 [95% confidence interval (CI): 1.012 to 1.203; p ¼ 0.027] and aHR: 1.084 [95% CI: 1.004 to 1.172; p ¼ 0.04], respectively). However, neither the Volume method nor RVEF (entered separately in the models due to high collinearity) was a predictor of events (aHR: 1.006 [95% CI: 0.833 to 1.214; p ¼ 0.952] and aHR: 0.996 [95% CI: 0.976 to 1.016; p ¼ 0.687]) (Figure 1). Models' goodness of fit and discrimination were comparable for all methods, with an Akaike information criterion of 580 and Harrel C statistic of 0.68. An analysis restricted to patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension produced similar findings (data not shown). In individuals with relatively preserved RV function (RVEF >35%), neither the Hybrid nor Flow method was associated with outcomes after adjusting for RVEF. However, the Volume method and RVEF (both entered separately) remained associated with mortality (aHR: 3.394 [95% CI: 1.284 to 8.975; p ¼ 0.014] and aHR: 0.942 [95% CI: 0.900 to 0.985; p ¼ 0.009], respectively). Conversely, in patients with RVEF #35%, the Hybrid and Flow methods were independently associated with mortality (aHR: 1.128 [95% CI: 1.030 to 1.235; p ¼ 0.009] and aHR: 1.105 [95% CI: 1.021 to 1.196; p ¼ 0.014]) after adjusting for RVEF, but the Volume method and RVEF were not.As expected, given the mathematical relationship between the CMR volume method and RVEF, these 2 approaches exhibited a perfect (curvilinear) correlation. Our results suggest that estimates of right ventriculoarterial coupling that use CMR-based ESV and PA flow-derived SV, alone or in combination with RHC, predict survival in this heterogeneous cohort of patients with PH and may be advantageous over RVEF in certain scenarios such as severe RV dysfunction. The reasons remain speculative, but they may be related to a wider range of possible values once RVEF is low, due to the still curvilinear relationships with RVEF (data not shown) and/or less preload dependency than RVEF, which requires enddiastolic volume for calculation (4).Our findings are limited by the retrospective and observational nature of this study from a single tertiary center, as well as by the inclusion of multiple PH etiologies.

TABREF139.text: Epicardial Adipose Tissue in Patients WithStable Chest Pain Insights From the PROMISE TrialA growing body of evidence, primarily based on cohorts with low cardiovascular risk, suggests that epicardial adipose tissue (EAT), a metabolically active tissue surrounding coronary arteries, is associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) and adverse car-diac events (1,2). However, little is known about the predictive value of EAT in symptomatic patients with elevated cardiovascular risk. We investigated Evaluation of Chest Pain) trial, a symptomatic cohort with increased cardiovascular risk (3). We included PROMISE patients who underwent cardiac computed tomography (CT) imaging and observed them for a median of 2 years for adverse cardiac events (composite of death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and hospitalization for unstable angina) (3). Local and central institutional review boards approved the study, and all patients provided written informed consent. Our dedicated core laboratory measured EAT volume (indexed by body surface area, in cubic centimeters per square meter) and attenuation (Hounsfield unit [HU]) on noncontrast electrocardiography-gated CT imaging.

TABREF140.text: calcium (CAC) score, CAD extent (segment involvement score [SIS]), and presence of high-risk plaque features (HRPF), including spotty calcium, positive remodeling, napkin ring sign, and low attenuation plaque. Our statistical analysis compared EAT volume between men and women, elderly ($65 years of age) and younger patients, across categories of CAC, and in those with 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk scores $7.5% versus <7.5%, SIS $4 versus <4, and HRPF present versus absent. In time-to-event analysis, we tested the association between EAT and events, unadjusted and adjusting for ASCVD risk. In 3,948 patients (mean age 60.6 AE 8.3 years; 51% female), mean EAT volume and attenuation were 57.5 AE 22.0 cm 3 /m 2 and -86.8 AE 5.1 HU, respectively. Men presented with higher EAT volume and attenuation compared with women (p < 0.05 for all) (

TABREF141.text: Overall, 128 (3.2%) patients experienced events during a median follow-up of 26.1 (18.0 to34.4)    months. Greater EAT volume was associated with a higher relative hazard of adverse events (hazard ratio per increase of 10 cm 3 /m 2 EAT volume: 1.01; 95%confidence interval: 1.00 to 1.15; p ¼ 0.036) in univariate analysis. However, this association attenuated after adjustment for the ASCVD risk (p ¼ 0.264). EAT attenuation was not associated with events (p ¼ 0.409). In patients with stable chest pain and increased cardiovascular risk, we found higher EAT volume in male subjects, the elderly, and those with increased cardiovascular risk and advanced CAD (i.e., higher CAC score, SIS, HRPF). Nevertheless, these observations did not translate into an association between EAT volume and adverse events beyond traditional cardiovascular risk factors. In accord with Mancio et al. (1), a meta-analysis with w20,000 asymptomatic, low-risk subjects from mostly large longitudinal studies with long-term follow-up (e.g., FHS [Framingham Heart Study], MESA [Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis], HNR [Heinz Nixdorf Recall] study, EISNER [Early Identification of Subclinical Atherosclerosis by Noninvasive Imaging Research] study, and the Rotterdam study), our results showed a strong relationship between EAT, cardiovascular risk factors, and extent of CAD. However, we did not find an independent association between EAT volume and adverse events.In a symptomatic population, EAT may have low short-term prognostic utility due to many confounding elements such as clinical risk factors, presence of established CAD, and management strategy (e.g., medical therapy, revascularization). These elements are physician dependent and may have varied between sites due to the pragmatic design of the PROMISE trial. Moreover, PROMISE patients already had an indication for CTA, based on their symptoms and pretest probability. Although longitudinal studies in asymptomatic cohorts have shown independent predictive prognostic value for deep learning-derived EAT, independent of ASCVD risk score (2), the prognostic relationship may be attenuated for symptomatic patients undergoing CTA due to the reasons mentioned earlier.We found no relationship between overall EAT attenuation and events. Thus, the cardiovascular riskFIGURE 1 EAT on Cardiac CT Imaging EAT Segmentation on Cardiac CT EAT by CV Risk Factors and CAD on CT * Deep learning (DL) segmentation system was trained on manually segmented CTs from the Framingham Heart Study (n = 628), PROMISE (n = 130), and National Lung Screening Trial (n = 100). The system reached a high accuracy in an independent subset of 1,010 PROMISE patients with manual EAT measurements (median dice: 0.952; IQR: 0.943-0.958).may be better predicted by the local attenuation of EAT directly adjacent to the coronaries. As reported by others, peri-coronary EAT attenuation has shown a strong association with cardiovascular events (4). The differences may be due to the local effects of EAT versus the global attenuation assessed in our study.To conclude, our results show a limited short-term predictive value of EAT in symptomatic patients with increased cardiovascular risk. Further research is needed to identify factors influencing the relationship between EAT and adverse outcomes.

TABREF142.text: There was moderate agreement between the 2 methods for classifying significant DD (Cohen's Kappa ¼ 0.59; p < 0.001), with reclassification noted in 5%: 18% had significant DD according to the ASE/ EACVI algorithms, whereas 23% had significant DD according to the combined algorithm. With respect to outcomes, there were a total of 40 MACEs (median follow-up 24 months). Significant DD was associated with MACEs on Kaplan-Meier analysis (log-rank chisquare: 22.08; p < 0.001). In a multivariate Cox proportional hazards model that incorporated significant clinical factors (age, chronic kidney disease) and LV ejection fraction (LVEF), significant DD was the most powerful predictor of outcomes (hazard ratio: 2.71; 95% confidence interval: 1.28 to 5.71; p ¼ 0.008), and its inclusion in sequential models produced a significant increment in the chi-square model. In the hemodynamic study, the mean LVEF was 43.8 AE 23.7% and the mean LVEDP was 15.4 AE 7.5 mm Hg. LVEDP was elevated in patients with significant DD: mean LVEDP 21.1 AE 7.9 mm Hg versus 13.2 AE 6.1 mm Hg (p ¼ 0.001). Receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curves showed an area under the curve of 0.814 (p < 0.001) for assessing elevated LVEDP. The calculated sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value for LVEDP $15 mm Hg were 41.7%, 87.1%, 78.9%, and 56.3%, respectively. On the relative merits of septal or average é, average é had a better correlation with LVEDP than septal é (r ¼ 0.27; p ¼ 0.009 compared with r ¼ 0.017; p ¼ 0.867). However, more importantly, both septal and average E/é showed a significant correlation with LVEDP as previously reported (r ¼ 0.42 and r ¼ 0.47, respectively; all p < 0.001) (4).

The E/ é ratio relates best to LV early diastolic pressures, and the guidelines advocate estimation of these pressures (4,5). It is unknown whether similar accuracy of septal and average E/é ratios would still be observed had these earlier LV diastolic pressures been evaluated. The letter is not clear whether the use of pulmonary vein systolic to diastolic velocity ratio was applied, despite the LVEF.
